We usually start with the “plain‐vanilla” Debye theory for an isotropic 3D solid, in which all the low–energy acoustic phonons have a linear dispersion (ω ≈ v|k|). (In this case the number of modes with frequency less than ω grows as ω³, and one finds at very low temperature that the specific heat C ∝ T³.) However, graphite is not isotropic. Its strongly bonded carbon layers are weakly coupled by van der Waals forces. One consequence is that one of the acoustic modes – the one corresponding to out‐of–plane (or “bending”) vibrations – does not have a linear dispersion. In fact, in an isolated 2D layer of carbon (as in graphene) the bending mode is “soft” and has a quadratic dispersion, ω ≈ α k², at long wavelengths.

Let us explain step by step how this leads to C ∝ T:

Step 1. Splitting the Phonon Modes

In graphite the in–plane (highly bonded) modes have a linear dispersion just as in the 3D Debye model. In contrast, the weak inter–layer (out–of–plane) coupling means that the corresponding acoustic vibration (which one may view as the “bending” mode) is nearly two–dimensional and displays a quadratic dispersion for small in–plane wave–vectors. (There may be a crossover to 3D behavior at higher energies, but at low T the quadratic behavior dominates.)

Step 2. Density of States for a Quadratic Dispersion in 2D

For a general dispersion law in d dimensions one finds that the number of modes with frequency less than ω, N(ω), is obtained by counting the allowed k–states. For a 2D system with quadratic dispersion (ω ≈ α k²), solving for k gives k ≈ √(ω/α). Thus, the “volume” (area in 2D) in k–space with |k| ≤ √(ω/α) is proportional to (ω/α). Hence, the number of states (and, differentiating, the density of states) is

  g(ω) ∝ dN/dω ∝ constant (i.e. independent of ω).

Step 3. Low–Temperature Behavior of the Specific Heat

Now, when g(ω) is roughly constant (say, g(ω) ≈ g₀ for low frequencies), the internal energy from such modes is given by

  U ∝ ∫₀^∞ dω   g₀ (ħω) / (e^(βħω) − 1).

Making the change x = βħω, this yields

  U ∝ g₀ (k_B T)² ∫₀^∞ dx   x/(e^x − 1).

That integral is finite, so one immediately obtains

  U ∝ T²  ⇒  C = dU/dT ∝ T.

Step 4. Conclusion

Thus, by adapting Debye theory to account for the anisotropic dispersion – namely, treating the out–of–plane bending mode as having a quadratic dispersion (with a constant density of states) – one naturally obtains a contribution to the phonon specific heat that is linear in temperature at low T. In graphite, this mode dominates the low–temperature specific heat, explaining why experimentally one finds C ∝ T.

We wish to compare the energy–momentum balance on two very different “planets”: a large one (the Earth) and a tiny one (a “chondrule” of radius 0.1 cm) when both are bathed in the radiation from an idealized “sun” (a black‐body of temperature Tₛ = 6000 K and radius Rₛ = 7×10¹⁰ cm) at a distance d = 1.5×10¹³ cm. (For simplicity, note that we are using cgs units throughout; you may convert to SI units if desired.) We assume that (i) the Earth absorbs all the radiation on its cross‐sectional (πR_E²) area, but reradiates uniformly over its full surface area (4πR_E²) so that its temperature is uniform, and (ii) the chondrule is a spherical, perfectly conducting blackbody. (In the latter case one must be a little careful because a small, rapidly–rotating sphere does not have a uniform temperature if the radiative timescale is short compared with the rotation period, but here we are concerned only with the order–of–magnitude forces.)

Let us work through each part carefully.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Temperature of the Earth

The luminosity of the sun is

  Lₛ = 4π Rₛ² σ Tₛ⁴,

so that at distance d the radiant power per unit area (the “flux”) is

  F = Lₛ/(4π d²) = σ Tₛ⁴ (Rₛ/d)².

Now the Earth intercepts an energy rate

  (P_in)_Earth = (π R_E²) F = π R_E² σTₛ⁴ (Rₛ/d)².

Because the Earth is assumed to have a very effective internal heat transport, its entire surface (area 4π R_E²) is at uniform temperature T_E and radiates

  (P_out)_Earth = 4π R_E² σT_E⁴.

Balance (P_in = P_out) gives

  π R_E² σTₛ⁴ (Rₛ/d)² = 4π R_E² σT_E⁴.

Canceling the common factors (πR_E²σ) we deduce

  Tₛ⁴ (Rₛ/d)² = 4 T_E⁴   ⟹  T_E⁴ = (Rₛ²/(4 d²)) Tₛ⁴.

Taking fourth roots we obtain

  T_E = Tₛ (Rₛ²/(4 d²))^(1/4)
     = Tₛ (Rₛ/(2d))^(1/2).

Now plug in the numbers:
  Rₛ = 7×10¹⁰ cm,  d = 1.5×10¹³ cm.
Thus,
  Rₛ/(2d) = (7×10¹⁰)/(2×1.5×10¹³) = 7×10¹⁰/3×10¹³ ≈ 2.33×10^(–3).
Taking the square root gives
  √(2.33×10^(–3)) ≈ 0.0483.
Then
  T_E ≈ 6000 K × 0.0483 ≈ 290 K.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Radiation Force on the Earth

The radiation pressure for an electromagnetic flux F is (for a perfectly absorbing surface)
  P_rad = F/c.

Since the Earth intercepts the flux on its circular “shadow” area π R_E², the momentum per unit time (force) imparted is

  F_rad = (π R_E²)(F/c).

But we already have

  F = σTₛ⁴ (Rₛ/d)²,
so

  F_rad = (π R_E²/c) σTₛ⁴ (Rₛ/d)².

Let’s collect the formula:
  F_rad = π R_E² σTₛ⁴ (Rₛ/d)² / c.

We now plug in numerical values:
  σ (the Stefan–Boltzmann constant in cgs) ≈ 5.67×10^(–5) erg/(cm²·s·K⁴),
  Tₛ = 6000 K,
  R_E = 6×10⁸ cm,
  Rₛ = 7×10^(10) cm,
  d = 1.5×10^(13) cm,
  c = 3×10^(10) cm/s.

Proceed step by step:

1. Compute Tₛ⁴:
  Tₛ⁴ = (6000)⁴ = (6×10³)⁴ = 6⁴ × 10^(12) = 1296×10^(12) = 1.296×10^(15).

2. Compute (Rₛ/d)²:
  (Rₛ/d) = (7×10^(10))/(1.5×10^(13)) ≈ 4.667×10^(–3),
  so (Rₛ/d)² ≈ (4.667×10^(–3))² ≈ 2.18×10^(–5).

3. Compute πR_E²:
  R_E² = (6×10⁸)² = 36×10^(16) = 3.6×10^(17),
  thus πR_E² ≈ 3.14×3.6×10^(17) ≈ 1.13×10^(18) cm².

Now assemble:
  F_rad = [1.13×10^(18) cm² × 5.67×10^(–5) erg/(cm²·s·K⁴) × 1.296×10^(15) K⁴ × 2.18×10^(–5)] / (3×10^(10) cm/s).

Calculate the numerator first:
  1.13×10^(18) × 5.67×10^(–5) ≈ 6.42×10^(13).
Multiply by 1.296×10^(15) gives
  6.42×10^(13) × 1.296×10^(15) ≈ 8.32×10^(28).
Multiply by 2.18×10^(–5) gives
  8.32×10^(28) × 2.18×10^(–5) ≈ 1.81×10^(24) erg/s.
Now divide by c = 3×10^(10) cm/s:
  F_rad ≈ (1.81×10^(24))/(3×10^(10)) ≈ 6.03×10^(13) dynes.

Thus the Earth experiences a radiation force of roughly 6×10^(13) dynes.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Comparison with a Chondrule

Now consider a small spherical “chondrule” of radius R = 0.1 cm. (We neglect here the complications of non–uniform temperature; assume for now that it is a black‐body which quickly comes to an “equilibrium” so that the flux balance is similar to before.)

(i) Equilibrium Temperature:
For any sphere that absorbs isotropically the incoming solar radiation over its geometric cross–section πR² and re–emits over 4πR², the equilibrium temperature is given by the same energy–balance:
  πR² σTₛ⁴ (Rₛ/d)² = 4πR² σT_eq⁴,
which implies
  T_eq⁴ = (Rₛ²/(4d²)) Tₛ⁴  ⟹  T_eq = Tₛ (Rₛ/(2d))^(1/2).
Thus, the chondrule’s equilibrium temperature is exactly the same as that of the Earth – about 290 K – provided that it rotates fast enough (or is small enough) to have a nearly uniform surface temperature. (In reality, if its temperature is non–uniform, its effective “recoil force” may (via the Yarkovsky effect) drive a non–radial acceleration.)

(ii) Radiation Force:
The radiation force on the chondrule, again assuming it simply absorbs (or equivalently, re–emits isotropically) is
  F_rad,chond = (πR²/c) σTₛ⁴ (Rₛ/d)².
Since here R = 0.1 cm, compared with R_E = 6×10^(8) cm for the Earth, the ratio of the forces scales as (R/chond/R_E)². Thus, one may write
  (F_rad,chond)/(F_rad,Earth) = (R/chond / R_E)²
    = (0.1/(6×10^(8)))².
A quick computation gives:
  (0.1)² = 0.01 and (6×10^(8))² = 3.6×10^(17). Thus,
  (F_rad,chond)/(F_rad,Earth) ≈ 0.01/3.6×10^(17) ≈ 2.78×10^(–20).
Since we found F_rad,Earth ≈ 6×10^(13) dynes, the chondrule force is
  F_rad,chond ≈ 6×10^(13) × 2.78×10^(–20) ≈ 1.67×10^(–6) dynes.
Thus, while the tiny chondrule is heated to nearly the same temperature as the Earth, the total momentum received by it from solar radiation is extremely small compared to that on the Earth. (Note also that for a small rotating body the re–emission may not be exactly isotropic in the heliocentric frame; this is the origin of the Yarkovsky effect, which can lead to non–radial accelerations that are, however, typically smaller by a factor ∼ v/c.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The Earth’s equilibrium temperature is 
  T_E = Tₛ (Rₛ/(2d))^(1/2) ≈ 290 K.

(b) The radiation force on the Earth is 
  F_rad ≈ (π R_E² σTₛ⁴/c)(Rₛ/d)² ≈ 6×10^(13) dynes.

(c) A 0.1‐cm chondrule (if rotating fast enough to be nearly isothermal) comes to essentially the same temperature, T ≈ 290 K, but its intercepted area is many orders of magnitude smaller so that 
  F_rad,chond ≈ 1.7×10^(–6) dynes;
in addition, any anisotropic re–emission can give rise to a small “Yarkovsky” force.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Boxed Format

\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad T_{E} &= T_S \left(\frac{R_S}{2d}\right)^{1/2} \approx 290\,\mathrm{K},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad F_{\rm rad, Earth} &= \frac{\pi R_{E}^2\,\sigma T_S^4}{c}\left(\frac{R_S}{d}\right)^2 \approx 6\times10^{13}\,\mathrm{dyn},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad \text{For a chondrule of }R=0.1\,\mathrm{cm}:&\\[0.5mm]
T_{\rm eq} &\approx 290\,\mathrm{K},\\[0.5mm]

}

We are given one mole of an ideal gas initially at t = 0°C (i.e. T = 273.15 K).

────────────────────────
Step 1. (a) Isothermal Expansion Work

For an isothermal process (constant temperature) in an ideal gas, the work done by the gas when expanding from volume V₀ to 10V₀ is given by

  W = nRT ln(V_f/V_i).

Here,
  n = 1 mole,
  R = 8.314 J/(mol·K),
  T = 273.15 K (0°C), and
  V_f/V_i = 10.

Therefore:

  W = (1 mol)(8.314 J/mol·K)(273.15 K) ln(10).

Recalling ln(10) ≈ 2.3026, we calculate:

  W ≈ 8.314 × 273.15 × 2.3026.

First, compute 8.314 × 273.15 ≈ 2272 J. Then multiplying by 2.3026 gives:

  W ≈ 2272 × 2.3026 ≈ 5230 J.

────────────────────────
Step 2. (b) Adiabatic Reversible Expansion Final Temperature

For a reversible adiabatic (no heat exchange) process in an ideal gas, the temperature and volume are related by

  T V^(γ–1) = constant,

where γ (gamma) is the heat capacity ratio, γ = Cₚ/Cᵥ.

For many diatomic gases at room temperature, a common approximation is γ = 1.4 (if not otherwise specified). (Note: For a monatomic ideal gas, γ = 5/3, but since many common gases are diatomic at T ≃ 273.15 K, we will use γ = 1.4.)

Let the initial state be (T_i, V_i) and the final state be (T_f, V_f). Then

  T_i V_i^(γ–1) = T_f V_f^(γ–1).

Substitute T_i = 273.15 K, V_i = V₀, and V_f = 10V₀:

  273.15 × V₀^(γ–1) = T_f × (10V₀)^(γ–1).

Notice that (10V₀)^(γ–1) = 10^(γ–1) V₀^(γ–1) so the V₀^(γ–1) cancels. We then have

  273.15 = T_f × 10^(γ–1).

Solving for T_f:

  T_f = 273.15 / 10^(γ–1).

With γ = 1.4, we get γ – 1 = 0.4 and 

  10^(0.4) ≈ 2.5119.

Thus,

  T_f ≈ 273.15 / 2.5119 ≈ 108.8 K.

Finally, converting to Celsius:

  t_f (°C) = T_f (K) – 273.15 ≈ 108.8 – 273.15 ≈ –164.35 °C.

────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The work done in the isothermal expansion is approximately 5230 J.
(b) The final temperature after a reversible adiabatic expansion to 10V₀ is about –164 °C.

We begin by noting that the energy levels for the vibrational degree of freedom of a diatomic molecule (modeled as a harmonic oscillator) are given by

  Eₙ = ℏω₀(n + ½)   (n = 0, 1, 2, …)

where ω₀ is the vibrational frequency and we define

  θ = ℏω₀/k.

Because the zero‐point energy (½ℏω₀) does not change with temperature, it does not contribute to the specific heat. However, it does appear in the partition function. Our goal is to derive the vibrational specific heat C_vib as a function of temperature.

Step 1. Write the Vibrational Partition Function

The vibrational partition function is

  Z_vib = Σₙ exp[–βEₙ] = Σₙ exp[–βℏω₀(n + ½)]
      = exp(–βℏω₀/2) Σₙ exp(–βℏω₀ n).

Recognizing the sum as a geometric series (with common ratio exp(–βℏω₀), which is less than 1 for positive temperature), we have

  Σₙ exp(–βℏω₀ n) = 1 / [1 – exp(–βℏω₀)].

Thus,

  Z_vib = exp(–βℏω₀/2) / [1 – exp(–βℏω₀)]
      = exp(–θ/(2T)) / [1 – exp(–θ/T)],      (since β = 1/(kT)).

Step 2. Calculate the Internal Energy

The internal energy U is given by

  U = –∂/∂β ln Z_vib.

First, compute ln Z_vib:
  ln Z_vib = –(βℏω₀)/2 – ln[1 – exp(–βℏω₀)]
       = –(θ/(2T)) – ln[1 – exp(–θ/T)].

Taking the derivative with respect to β (or equivalently with respect to T) will give the full internal energy including the zero-point contribution. However, as mentioned, the zero-point energy (first term) is independent of T and does not contribute to the specific heat. Therefore, we focus on the temperature dependent part.

A standard result (which you can derive by differentiating ln Z_vib with respect to β) shows that the mean vibrational energy is:

  U = (½ℏω₀) + ℏω₀/(exp(ℏω₀/(kT)) – 1)
    = (½ kθ) + kθ/(exp(θ/T) – 1).

For the specific heat C_vib, we differentiate U with respect to T. Since the zero-point contribution (½kθ) is constant, only the second term contributes:

  U_vib(T) = kθ/(exp(θ/T) – 1).

Step 3. Differentiate U_vib to Find C_vib

The vibrational specific heat is

  C_vib = dU_vib/dT.

Let x = θ/T so that U_vib = kθ/(eˣ – 1). Then

  dU_vib/dT = d/dT [kθ/(e^(θ/T) – 1)].

Differentiate with respect to T using the chain rule. Notice that

  d(e^(θ/T))/dT = –(θ/T²) e^(θ/T).

Thus,
  dU_vib/dT = kθ · d/dT [1/(e^(θ/T) – 1)]
        = – kθ · [e^(θ/T)/(e^(θ/T) – 1)²] · d/dT(e^(θ/T))
        = – kθ · [e^(θ/T)/(e^(θ/T) – 1)²] · (–θ/T² e^(θ/T))
        = kθ²/T² · [e^(θ/T) · e^(θ/T)]/(e^(θ/T) – 1)²
        = k (θ/T)² · [e^(θ/T)]/(e^(θ/T) – 1)².

Thus, the vibrational specific heat is given by

  C_vib = k (θ/T)² · [e^(θ/T)]/(e^(θ/T) – 1)².

Step 4. High and Low Temperature Limits

a) High Temperature Limit (T >> θ):

When T >> θ, the quantity x = θ/T is very small. Then we can expand the exponential in a Taylor series:

  e^(θ/T) ≈ 1 + (θ/T) + ½ (θ/T)² + …

Thus, e^(θ/T) – 1 ≈ θ/T. Plugging into the expression for C_vib:

  C_vib ≈ k (θ/T)² · [1 + (θ/T)]/(θ/T)² ≈ k.

This is the classical Dulong-Petit result for a one-dimensional (harmonic oscillator) degree of freedom, which contributes k to the specific heat (remember, a harmonic oscillator has two quadratic degrees of freedom – kinetic and potential – but here the vibrational partition function already accounts for both).

b) Low Temperature Limit (T << θ):

When T << θ, x = θ/T is very large. Then, e^(θ/T) >> 1, and

  e^(θ/T) – 1 ≈ e^(θ/T).

In this limit,

  C_vib ≈ k (θ/T)² · e^(θ/T)/(e^(θ/T))² = k (θ/T)² e^(–θ/T).

Thus, at low temperatures the vibrational contribution to the specific heat is exponentially suppressed, approaching zero as T → 0.

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{C_{\text{vib}} = k \left(\frac{\theta}{T}\right)^2 \frac{e^{\theta/T}}{\left(e^{\theta/T} - 1\right)^2}}
\]

High Temperature Limit: For T >> θ, C_vib → k.

Low Temperature Limit: For T << θ, C_vib ~ k (θ/T)² e^(–θ/T) → 0.

We wish to “order‐of‐magnitude” estimate several quantities. In our estimates we assume that air is an ideal diatomic gas (mainly N₂ and O₂) and that a “room” is a typical one (with a volume of several tens of cubic meters). In what follows we describe one way to “get the answer.”

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Estimate the Number of Molecules in a Room

A common “back‐of‐the‐envelope” method is to imagine a room of volume roughly 50 m³. (For example, a 5×5×2 m room has 50 m³ volume.)

The density of air is about
  ρ ≈ 1.2 kg/m³.
Then the total mass of air is
  m ≈ (1.2 kg/m³)(50 m³) = 60 kg.
Air is mostly diatomic with a molar mass M ≈ 29 g/mol = 0.029 kg/mol. Thus, the number of moles is
  n ≈ 60 kg / 0.029 kg/mol ≈ 2069 mol.
Since one mole contains Avogadro’s number NA ≈ 6.02×10²³ molecules, the total number of molecules is
  N ≈ 2069 mol × 6.02×10²³ molecules/mol ≈ 1.25×10²⁷ molecules.
Thus, (a) we have roughly 10²⁷ molecules in a typical room.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Estimate Their Energy, Per Mole

“Energy” here is taken to mean the thermal (internal) energy contained in an ideal gas. For a monatomic ideal gas the translational kinetic energy per mole would be (3/2)RT. However, for diatomic molecules (with no vibrational excitation at room temperature) there are 3 translational and 2 rotational degrees of freedom so that the internal energy is
  U = (5/2)RT  (per mole).
Taking room temperature T ≈ 293 K and R = 8.314 J/(mol·K) we have

  U ≈ (5/2)(8.314 J/(mol·K))(293 K)
     ≈ 5/2 × 2437 J/mol 
     ≈ 6093 J/mol.
Thus, (b) the energy per mole is roughly 6×10³ joules (or 6×10¹⁰ ergs per mole, since 1 J = 10⁷ ergs).

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Heat Needed to Warm One Mole of Air from 0°C to 20°C

At constant pressure the heat needed to raise the temperature of one mole of an ideal gas (with constant‐pressure molar heat capacity Cp) is given by
  Q = n·Cp·ΔT  with n = 1.
For a diatomic gas, the molar heat capacity at constant pressure is
  Cp = (7/2)R,
so that numerically
  Cp ≈ (7/2)(8.314 J/(mol·K)) ≈ 29.1 J/(mol·K).
The temperature change is ΔT = 20°C (remembering the change is the same in Kelvin), so
  Q ≈ (29.1 J/(mol·K))×20 K ≈ 582 J.
Thus, (c) about 600 J of heat must be added to warm one mole of air from 0°C to 20°C.

──────────────────────────────
Step (d): Minimum Energy Required by a Refrigerator

Now we wish to “cool” one mole of air at 1 atm from 20°C to 18°C. That is, we want to remove a small amount of heat from the air. In a cyclic (reversible) refrigerator the minimum work required is not the same as the thermal energy removed; the ratio is given by the Carnot coefficient of performance (COP). For a refrigerator operating between a “cold” reservoir at temperature TL (the temperature at which heat is removed) and a “hot” reservoir at temperature TH (the temperature at which the heat is rejected) the Carnot COP is

  COP = TL/(TH – TL).
In our problem, the refrigerator “rejects” heat at 40°C, i.e. TH = 313 K. Since the cooling is taking the air from 20°C to 18°C, the heat is removed over a small range. (One may think of it as being removed at nearly 20°C; for a more careful treatment one could integrate over temperature. Here we take an effective TL of about 292 K—the average between 293 K and 291 K.)
Thus, approximately,
  COP ≈ 292 K/(313 K – 292 K) = 292/21 ≈ 13.9.
The cooling load is the amount of heat removed in cooling one mole from 20°C to 18°C. At constant pressure, with Cp ≈ 29.1 J/(mol·K) as above, that heat is
  Qc = Cp·ΔT = 29.1 J/(mol·K) × 2 K ≈ 58 J.
The minimum work required is then
  W_min = Qc/COP ≈ 58 J/13.9 ≈ 4.17 J.
Thus, (d) the minimum energy that must be supplied to the refrigerator is roughly 4 J.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) ~1×10²⁷ molecules  
(b) ~6×10³ J per mole (≈6×10¹⁰ ergs/mol)  
(c) ~6×10² J (≈600 J) per mole  
(d) ~4 J of work (minimum) per mole

In summary, our final answers are:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}&\; N\sim1\times10^{27}\,\text{molecules},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}&\; U\sim\frac{5}{2}RT\sim6\times10^3\,\text{J/mol},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}&\; Q\sim C_p\Delta T\sim600\, \text{J},\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}&\; W_{\min}=\frac{Q}{\rm COP}\sim4\,\text{J}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We begin by recalling the definition of the two heat capacities. For any system, the heat capacity at constant volume is

  C₍ᵥ₎ = (dU/dT)₍V₎

and at constant pressure the heat capacity is defined by

  C₍ₚ₎ = (dH/dT)₍p₎

where the enthalpy H is given by

  H = U + pV.

Differentiating H with respect to T at constant pressure gives

  dH/dT = dU/dT + p (dV/dT).

Thus,
  C₍ₚ₎ = C₍ᵥ₎ + p (dV/dT).

In many solids (to a good approximation) the internal energy U depends only on temperature (and not on volume). This means that the differentiation dU/dT at constant pressure is the same as at constant volume. Therefore, we have

  C₍ₚ₎ – C₍ᵥ₎ = p (dV/dT).

Now, the coefficient of volumetric expansion β is defined by

  β = (1/V)(∂V/∂T)₍ₚ₎.

For an isotropic solid the volume change is related to the linear thermal expansion coefficient α by

  β = 3α.

Thus, rearranging the definition of β we have

  (∂V/∂T)₍ₚ₎ = V β = 3α V.

For a solid of total mass M and density ρ the total volume is

  V = M/ρ.

Plugging this into our expression for the difference in heat capacities we obtain

  C₍ₚ₎ – C₍ᵥ₎ = p (3α V) = 3α p (M/ρ).

Thus, the final relation between the heat capacities C₍ₚ₎ and C₍ᵥ₎ for the solid is

  C₍ₚ₎ – C₍ᵥ₎ = (3α M p)/ρ.

So, the final answer is:

  \[\boxed{C_p - C_v=\frac{3\alpha M p}{\rho}}\]

We start with 10 L of an ideal gas at 1 atm. The gas is first compressed isothermally (constant temperature) to 1 L and then allowed to expand adiabatically (no heat exchange) back to 10 L. Although the cycle does not return to the same thermodynamic state (the temperature is lower at the end), we may still “sketch” the two processes on a pV diagram and compare the work exchanges for a monatomic versus a diatomic gas.

Let’s analyze step‐by‐step.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Step 1. Isothermal Compression

For an ideal gas at constant temperature, the equation pV = const holds. The initial state is (V₁ = 10 L, p₁ = 1 atm) so that pV = 10 (L·atm). Compressing isothermally to V₂ = 1 L means that
  p₂ = 10 atm.
Thus on a pV diagram the isothermal compression is a hyperbola connecting (10, 1 atm) to (1, 10 atm).

The work done (from the gas–perspective) in an isothermal process is

  W_iso = –nRT ln(V₂/V₁).

(Here the negative sign means that when the gas is compressed, work is done on it.)

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Step 2. Adiabatic Expansion

During an adiabatic process the relation

  pV^γ = constant

holds. However, the value of γ (the heat capacity ratio) depends on the gas:
• For a monatomic gas, γ = 5/3 ≈ 1.67.
• For a diatomic gas (with vibrational modes “frozen out”), γ ≈ 7/5 = 1.4.

At the beginning of the adiabatic expansion, the state is (V₂ = 1 L, p₂ = 10 atm). When the gas expands adiabatically to V₃ = 10 L, the final pressures are determined by

  p₃ = p₂ (V₂/V₃)^γ.
So, for the two cases:
– Monatomic:
  p₃,mono = 10 atm × (1/10)^(5/3) = 10/10^(1.67) ≈ 10/46.4 ≈ 0.22 atm.
– Diatomic:
  p₃,di = 10 atm × (1/10)^(1.4) = 10/10^(1.4) ≈ 10/25.1 ≈ 0.40 atm.

Thus, on the same pV diagram the adiabatic expansion “curve” leaves the point (1, 10 atm) and reaches (10, 0.22 atm) for the monatomic gas and (10, 0.40 atm) for the diatomic gas.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
(a) and (b) Graphical sketches on a pV diagram

For both gases the diagram shows:
1. An isothermal compression curve – a hyperbola from (10, 1 atm) to (1, 10 atm).
2. An adiabatic expansion curve:
 – For the monatomic gas, a curve with the equation pV^(5/3) = constant connecting (1, 10 atm) to roughly (10, 0.22 atm). This curve falls more steeply.
 – For the diatomic gas, the adiabatic curve is given by pV^(1.4) = constant connecting (1, 10 atm) to roughly (10, 0.40 atm); it is not as steep as that for a monatomic gas.

A quick sketch would show these two curves on the same pV plot:
• The horizontal “volume” axis runs from 0 to a bit more than 10 L.
• The “pressure” axis starts near 0 and extends up to about 10 atm.
• For both cases, the isothermal compression is the same; only the adiabatic expansion curve differs.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
(c) Net Work Done

Now, regarding the net work done in this two‐step process:

1. In the isothermal compression from 10 L → 1 L, work is done on the system. (The gas does negative work; the surroundings do positive work on the gas.)

2. In the adiabatic expansion from 1 L → 10 L, the gas does work (it expands and produces work on the surroundings).

However, if we compute the magnitudes (using the ideal gas relations), we find that the work done by the gas during the adiabatic expansion does not “recover” all the work that was required during the isothermal compression. One may, for a rough analysis, note that the isothermal work magnitude is

  |W_iso| = nRT ln(10).

In the adiabatic expansion the work done by the gas (which equals the decrease in its internal energy, ΔU) depends on the heat capacity. For example, for a monatomic gas (with internal energy U = (3/2)nRT) the work in the adiabatic expansion comes out to be approximately

  W_ad,mono = (3/2)nRT [1 – 1/10^(2/3)].

A numerical estimate shows that for a monatomic gas the work output during expansion is less than nRT ln(10). Thus the overall net work (work done by the gas minus work done on it) is negative. That is, net work is done on the system.

Therefore, answer to (c): The net work is done on the system.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
(d) Comparison: Diatomic vs. Monatomic

For the diatomic gas the effective degrees of freedom are higher (with U = (5/2)nRT for a diatomic molecule at room temperature, ignoring vibrations), which makes the change in internal energy during the adiabatic expansion larger for the same change in temperature. In fact, one finds that the work done by the gas during the adiabatic expansion is
  W_ad,di = (5/2)nRT [1 – 1/10^(0.4)],
which turns out to be smaller in magnitude than the work done during the isothermal compression.

A short numerical comparison yields:
• For the monatomic gas, the net result is roughly –1.13 nRT.
• For the diatomic gas, the net result is roughly –0.80 nRT.
(The negative sign means that overall work is done on the gas – i.e. the surroundings supply net work.)

Thus, less net work is done on the diatomic gas than on the monatomic gas. (In other words, the diatomic gas returns more of the “compression work” during its expansion, so the “loss” is smaller.)

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Final Answers

(a) For a monatomic gas the pV diagram shows an isothermal hyperbola from (10 L, 1 atm) to (1 L, 10 atm) followed by an adiabatic curve given by pV^(5/3) = constant from (1, 10 atm) to approximately (10 L, 0.22 atm).

(b) For a diatomic gas the isothermal curve is the same but the adiabatic expansion (pV^(1.4) = constant) goes from (1, 10 atm) to about (10 L, 0.40 atm).

(c) The net work is negative (i.e. net work is done on the system).

(d) In magnitude, the net work done on the diatomic gas is less than that done on the monatomic gas.

Finally, our answer in boxed LaTeX is:

\[ \boxed{\begin{array}{l}
\text{(a) For a monatomic gas: An isothermal compression from (10\,L, 1\,atm) to (1\,L, 10\,atm) (pV = \text{constant}),} \\
\quad\text{followed by an adiabatic expansion (pV}^{5/3} = \text{ constant) from (1\,L, 10\,atm) to approximately (10\,L, 0.22\,atm).} \\
\text{(b) For a diatomic gas: The isothermal compression is identical, but the adiabatic expansion, obeying} \\
\quad\text{pV}^{1.4} = \text{ constant, goes from (1\,L, 10\,atm) to about (10\,L, 0.40\,atm).} \\
\text{(c) Overall, the net work is done on the system (the work done on compressing exceeds that recovered in expansion).} \\
\text{(d) The net work (in absolute value) is less for a diatomic gas than for a monatomic one.}
\end{array} } \]

\text{The work on the monatomic gas is greater than that on the diatomic gas.}

Step 1. Convert the solar constant to SI units.  
The solar constant is given as 0.1 W/cm². Since 1 cm² = 10⁻⁴ m², we have

  0.1 W/cm² = 0.1 / (10⁻⁴) W/m² = 10³ W/m².

Step 2. Write the relation between the solar flux at Earth and the Sun’s surface flux.  
Assume the Sun is a perfect blackbody. Its energy flux at the surface is given by the Stefan–Boltzmann law:

  F_sun = σ T_sun⁴,

where σ = 5.67×10⁻⁸ W/(m²·K⁴) and T_sun is the temperature of the Sun.

By the inverse-square law, the flux at Earth, S (the solar constant), is reduced by the factor (R_sun/d)²:

  S = σ T_sun⁴ (R_sun/d)².

Solving for T_sun, we get

  T_sun = [S d²/(σ R_sun²)]^(1/4).

Step 3. Insert the known values.  
Use the following approximate values:
  S = 10³ W/m²,  
  d = 1.5×10¹¹ m (Earth–Sun distance),  
  R_sun = 7×10⁸ m (solar radius).

Plug these into the equation:

  T_sun = [10³ × (1.5×10¹¹)² / (5.67×10⁻⁸ × (7×10⁸)²)]^(1/4).

Step 4. Perform the calculations step by step.

First, compute d² and R_sun²:
  d² = (1.5×10¹¹)² = 2.25×10²² m²,  
  R_sun² = (7×10⁸)² = 4.9×10¹⁷ m².

The numerator becomes:
  Numerator = 10³ × 2.25×10²² = 2.25×10²⁵.

The denominator is:
  Denom = 5.67×10⁻⁸ × 4.9×10¹⁷  
        = (5.67 × 4.9) ×10^(–8+17)
        ≈ 27.78×10⁹ = 2.78×10¹⁰.

Then, the ratio is:
  (2.25×10²⁵)/(2.78×10¹⁰) ≈ 8.09×10¹⁴.

Now, take the fourth root:
  T_sun = (8.09×10¹⁴)^(1/4).

To compute the fourth root, use logarithms or note that taking a fourth root is equivalent to taking a square root twice.

Taking the logarithm (base 10) approach:
  log₁₀(8.09×10¹⁴) = log₁₀(8.09) + 14 ≈ 0.91 + 14 = 14.91.
Dividing by 4 gives:
  14.91/4 ≈ 3.7275.
Thus, T_sun ≈ 10^(3.7275) ≈ 5.34×10³ K.

Step 5. Conclude with the final answer.  

The temperature of the Sun, assuming it is a black body and using the given solar constant, is approximately 5300 K.

Final answer in boxed notation:

\[
\boxed{T_{\rm sun} \approx 5.3\times10^3 \, \text{K}}
\]

We start with the general expression for the speed of small‐amplitude longitudinal waves (sound) in a gas:

  C = √(dp/dρ).

The key is to find dp/dρ under the specific conditions for each case.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Isothermal Process

For an isothermal process, the temperature T remains constant during the compressions and rarefactions. The ideal gas law for a fixed temperature is

  p = ρ R_specific T

where R_specific is the gas constant per unit mass. Since T is constant, we differentiate p with respect to ρ:

  dp/dρ = d(ρ R_specific T)/dρ = R_specific T.

Thus, the speed of sound in a gas with isothermal compressions is

  C_isothermal = √(R_specific T).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Adiabatic Process

For an adiabatic process, no heat is exchanged, and the pressure and density satisfy the relation

  p ρ^(−γ) = constant   or  p = constant · ρ^γ,
  
where γ is the adiabatic index (ratio of specific heats). Differentiating p with respect to ρ, we obtain

  dp/dρ = d(κ ρ^γ)/dρ = γ κ ρ^(γ−1).

But since κ ρ^γ is just p itself, we have

  dp/dρ = γ p/ρ.

Thus, the speed of sound in an adiabatic process is

  C_adiabatic = √(γ p/ρ).

Often, using the ideal gas law for an adiabatic process (where p/ρ = R_specific T), one may also express it as

  C_adiabatic = √(γ R_specific T).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The speed of sound in an isothermal process is

  \[
\boxed{C_\text{isothermal} = \sqrt{R_\text{specific}\,T}}
\]

(b) The speed of sound in an adiabatic process is

  \[
\boxed{C_\text{adiabatic} = \sqrt{\frac{\gamma\,p}{\rho}} = \sqrt{\gamma\,R_\text{specific}\,T}}
\]

We are given an expression for the entropy of an ideal gas

  S = (n/2)[σ + 5R ln(U/n) + 2R ln(V/n)],

where n is the number of moles, R is the universal gas constant, U is the internal energy, V is the volume, and σ is a constant.

Let us address each part step by step.

────────────────────────────┐
Step (a): Calculation of cₚ and cᵥ
────────────────────────────┘

Recall that in thermodynamics the temperature is related to the partial derivative of the entropy with respect to the internal energy (at constant V):

  (∂S/∂U)_V = 1/T.

Differentiate the given entropy with respect to U (keeping V constant):

  S = (n/2)[σ + 5R ln(U/n) + 2R ln(V/n)].

Only the term with U depends on U. We have

  d/dU [5R ln(U/n)] = (5R/U).

Thus,

  (∂S/∂U)_V = (n/2) · (5R/U) = (5Rn)/(2U).

Equate this to 1/T:

  (5Rn)/(2U) = 1/T  ⇒  U = (5RnT)/2.

This gives the internal energy as a function of temperature. The heat capacity at constant volume is defined as

  cᵥ = (∂U/∂T)_V.

Since U = (5Rn/2) T, it immediately follows that

  cᵥ = 5Rn/2  (per n moles).

Often, we report the specific heat per mole so that

  cᵥ (per mole) = 5R/2.

Now, using the well-known relation for an ideal gas

  cₚ = cᵥ + R,
  
we find

  cₚ (per mole) = (5R/2) + R = 7R/2.

────────────────────────────┐
Step (b): Comparison of Energy Density at Two Temperatures
────────────────────────────┘

The energy density is defined as the internal energy per unit volume, U/V. We found

  U = (5RnT)/2.

Thus,

  U/V = (5RnT)/(2V).

However, for an ideal gas the equation of state is

  pV = nRT  ⇒  n/V = p/(RT).

Substitute this into the expression for U/V:

  U/V = (5R T/2) · (n/V)
     = (5R T/2) · (p/(R T))
    = 5p/2.

Notice that the temperature (T) cancels out entirely. Therefore, under constant pressure (which is a good approximation for a house in a drafty environment), the energy density

  U/V = 5p/2

remains the same regardless of the temperature change. In other words, even though the air temperature in the house rises from 32°F to 70°F, the energy density (energy per volume) does not change, as long as the pressure remains constant.

────────────────────────────┐
Final Answers
────────────────────────────┘

(a) The specific heats for the gas are:
  cᵥ = 5R/2  and  cₚ = 7R/2  (per mole).

(b) The energy density is given by:
  U/V = 5p/2,
which implies that the energy density remains the same at 32°F as at 70°F when the pressure is constant.

Thus, the final answers are:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & c_v = \frac{5R}{2},\quad c_p = \frac{7R}{2}.\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & \frac{U}{V} = \frac{5p}{2} \quad\text{(which is independent of temperature at constant pressure)}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start with Dieterici’s equation of state

  p (V – b) = R T exp(–a/(R T V))  (1)

and wish to evaluate the ratio

  (pV/(RT))_c

at the critical point. At a critical point the p–V isotherm has an inflection point so that

  (∂p/∂V)_T = 0  and  (∂²p/∂V²)_T = 0  (critical conditions).

Step 1. Express p as a function of V and T.

Divide eq. (1) by (V – b):

  p = (R T/(V – b)) exp (–a/(R T V)).  (2)

Step 2. Write ln p and differentiate.

It is easier to work with the logarithm:

  ln p = ln(RT) – ln(V – b) – a/(R T V).  (3)

Differentiate eq. (3) with respect to V (at fixed T):

  d(ln p)/dV = – 1/(V – b) + a/(R T V²).  (4)

At the critical point, the first derivative of p must vanish. Since

  dp/dV = p·[d(ln p)/dV],
if d(ln p)/dV = 0 then dp/dV = 0. Thus the first condition gives:
  – 1/(V – b) + a/(R T V²) = 0  ⟹  a/(R T) = V²/(V – b).  (5)

Step 3. Use the second derivative condition.

Differentiate eq. (4) with respect to V:

  d²(ln p)/dV² = d/dV[–1/(V – b)] + d/dV[a/(R T V²)]
           = 1/(V – b)² – 2a/(R T V³).  (6)

At the critical point, we also require that
  d²p/dV² = p·[ (d(ln p)/dV)² + d²(ln p)/dV² ] = 0.
Since at the critical point d(ln p)/dV = 0, we need

  d²(ln p)/dV² = 0  ⟹  1/(V – b)² – 2a/(R T V³) = 0.  (7)

Solve eq. (7):

  1/(V – b)² = 2a/(R T V³)  ⟹  a/(R T) = V³/(2(V – b)²).  (8)

Step 4. Combine the two conditions (5) and (8).

From (5):  a/(R T) = V²/(V – b)
From (8):  a/(R T) = V³/(2(V – b)²)

Equate the right‐sides:

  V²/(V – b) = V³/(2(V – b)²).

Multiply both sides by 2(V – b)²:

  2V²(V – b) = V³.

Cancel a common factor V² (V > 0):

  2(V – b) = V.
  Thus,  V = 2b.

So the critical molar volume is

  V_c = 2b.

Step 5. Find T_c in terms of a, b, and R.

Substitute V_c = 2b into eq. (5):

  a/(R T_c) = V_c²/(V_c – b) = (4b²)/(2b – b) = (4b²)/b = 4b.

Thus

  T_c = a/(4bR).

Step 6. Determine p_c.

Return to eq. (2) for p:

  p = (R T/(V – b)) exp(–a/(R T V)).

At the critical point substitute T_c and V_c:

  p_c = (R T_c/(V_c – b)) exp(–a/(R T_c V_c)).

We have:
  V_c – b = 2b – b = b  and  T_c = a/(4bR).

Thus

  R T_c = a/(4b),
  so
  p_c = (a/(4b))/(b) exp(–a/(R T_c·2b))
     = (a/(4b²)) exp(–a/(2b R T_c)).

Now compute the exponent. Since T_c = a/(4bR):

  a/(2b R T_c) = a/(2b R · [a/(4bR)]) = a/(2bR) · (4bR/a) = 2.

Thus

  p_c = (a/(4b²)) exp(–2).  (9)

Step 7. Compute the ratio (pV/(RT)) at the critical point.

We need

  (pV/(RT))_c = (p_c V_c)/(R T_c).

We have:
  p_c = a/(4b²) exp(–2),
  V_c = 2b,
  R T_c = a/(4b).

Thus

  p_c V_c = [a/(4b²) exp(–2)]·(2b) = (2a/(4b)) exp(–2) = (a/(2b)) exp(–2),
  so
  (p_c V_c)/(R T_c) = [ (a/(2b)) exp(–2)] / [a/(4b)].

Simplify the ratio:

  (p_c V_c)/(R T_c) = exp(–2) · [ (a/(2b)) · (4b/a) ] = exp(–2) · (4/(2)) = 2 exp(–2).

Numerically,
  exp(–2) ≈ 0.135,
  so 2 exp(–2) ≈ 0.270.

Step 8. Final Answer

Thus, the ratio (pV/(RT)) at the critical point for a gas obeying Dieterici’s equation is

  (pV/(RT))_c = 2 e^(–2) ≈ 0.27  (accurate to two significant figures).

Final boxed answer:
  \[
\boxed{\frac{p_c V_c}{RT_c} = 2e^{-2} \approx 0.27}
\]

We will show that by combining thermodynamics with the (dynamical) measurement of the rubber’s “spring–constant” we can predict the isothermal (static) stretch of the band when a small extra weight is added. (In what follows “rubber” and “elastic band” are used interchangeably.)

Below is an outline of the reasoning.

───────────────────────────── Step 1. Thermodynamics of the Rubber Elasticity

For many rubber bands the dominant part of the “tension” is not an energetic effect but an entropic one. (In more‐traditional “Hooke’s law” springs the energy depends on the spring deformation; in rubber the internal energy is almost independent of length, and the force comes almost entirely from the change in entropy.) In a first–approximation one may write the free energy as

  F(L, T)= U(L) – T S(L).

Often one assumes U(L) ≈ constant so that 
  f ≡ ∂F/∂L = –T (dS/dL).

Thus the force is “entropic” – increasing with temperature and proportional to –(dS/dL). (A detailed microscopic calculation shows that indeed dS/dL is negative so that the tension f is positive.) 

───────────────────────────── Step 2. The Adiabatic Stretch (Measurement (a))

When the band is stretched very rapidly the process is nearly adiabatic (i.e. no heat is exchanged, so S stays constant). In any adiabatic process we have

  dS = (∂S/∂L)_T dL + (∂S/∂T)_L dT =0.

Solve for dT/dL:
  dT/dL = - (∂S/∂L)_T/(∂S/∂T)_L.

But the denominator is just the heat capacity at constant L (apart from a factor T), because
  (∂S/∂T)_L = C_L/T.
Also, we already have
  (dS/dL)_T = – f/T.
Thus
  dT/dL = – (– f/T) / (C_L/T) = f/C_L.
That is, during a rapid (adiabatic) stretch a small increase dL produces a temperature change
  dT = (f/C_L)dL         (1)

In an experiment one measures the temperature change ΔT when the band is stretched by a small amount ΔL adiabatically. Equation (1) then shows that the “instantaneous” tension in the band is given by

  f = C (ΔT/ΔL).         (2)

Here C is the appropriate heat capacity (we drop the subscript L).

───────────────────────────── Step 3. Small Oscillations (Measurement (b))

Now, in a separate experiment the band is held with one end fixed and a known weight W is attached to the other, and the frequency of small oscillations is measured (the assumption is that the oscillations are fast and nearly adiabatic). In a harmonic approximation the motion is described by

  m (d²(δL)/dt²) = – k_ad δL,
with the solution having frequency
  ν = (1/2π) √(k_ad/m),
so that we may define the “adiabatic spring constant”

  k_ad = (2πν)² m.         (3)

───────────────────────────── Step 4. Relating the “Isothermal” and the “Adiabatic” Spring‐constants

The static measurement (measurement (c)) is made slowly so that heat can be exchanged; thus it is an isothermal measurement. In thermodynamics the “spring–constant” when temperature is held constant (the curvature of the free–energy) is

  k_iso = (∂²F/∂L²)_T.
In contrast, the measured small oscillation constant is “adiabatic”:
  k_ad = (∂²U/∂L²)_S.
One may show by a standard thermodynamic argument (analogous to the relation between isothermal and adiabatic compressibilities) that

  k_ad = k_iso + (T/C)(∂f/∂T)_L².     (4)

Now, recall that we have
  f = – T (dS/dL).
Thus at fixed L,
  (∂f/∂T)_L = – (dS/dL) = f/T,     (since f = –T (dS/dL) ).
Then (4) becomes

  k_ad = k_iso + (T/C)(f/T)² = k_iso + f²/(C T).     (5)

We already determined in (2) that the tension in the adiabatic experiment is

  f = C (ΔT/ΔL).
Thus, (5) may be written as

  k_iso = k_ad – f²/(C T)
      = (2πν)²m – (C/T) (ΔT/ΔL)².     (6)

This k_iso is exactly the effective spring–constant that governs the isothermal (static) response.

───────────────────────────── Step 5. Prediction for the Static Stretch (Measurement (c))

When a small additional force (or weight) Q is applied slowly (so that the process is isothermal), the resulting additional extension δL is given by Hooke’s law

  Q = k_iso δL     or  δL = Q/k_iso.
Then, using (6) for k_iso we obtain

  δL = Q / [ (2πν)² m – (C/T) (ΔT/ΔL)² ].     (7)

This is the required relation: it expresses the size of the isothermal length–change under a small added weight in terms of the measured adiabatic temperature change per unit length (measurement (a)) and the measured frequency (measurement (b)).

───────────────────────────── Final Answer

Thus one acceptable final answer is

  δL = Q / { (2πν)² m – (C/T)[(ΔT)/(ΔL)]² }.

We note that in this formula:
 • ΔT and ΔL are measured in the rapid (adiabatic) stretching (experiment (a)),
 • ν (and m = W/g, with the weight W used in the oscillation experiment) comes from experiment (b),
 • and Q is the additional force (weight) added in experiment (c).

We box the answer in Latex format:

  \[
\boxed{\delta L = \frac{Q}{(2\pi \nu)^2\, m - \dfrac{C}{T}\left(\dfrac{\Delta T}{\Delta L}\right)^2}\,.}
\]

This is the prediction: given the adiabatic temperature change per unit stretch and the oscillation frequency, one can “predict” the static (isothermal) extension δL when an extra force Q is applied.

We begin by noting that a current I = 10 A passes through a resistor with resistance R = 100 Ω for a time t = 300 s. The power dissipated by the resistor is

  P = I² R = (10 A)² (100 Ω) = 100 × 100 = 10,000 W.

Thus, the total electrical energy converted to heat (which is eventually transferred to the thermal reservoir kept at 300 K) is

  Q = P × t = 10,000 W × 300 s = 3.0 × 10⁶ J.

Since the resistor is held at a constant temperature (300 K), its state remains unchanged. Now we analyze each part step by step.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 1: Entropy Change of the Resistor (a)

Even though the resistor transforms electrical energy into heat (Joule heating), because it is in contact with a thermal reservoir that keeps its temperature constant, any entropy generated internally is immediately dumped into the reservoir. In other words, the resistor itself does not undergo a net change in its state. Thus, we take

  ΔS_resistor = 0.
 
─────────────────────────────  
Step 2: Entropy Change of the Universe (b)

Here, we consider the effect on the reservoir (or surroundings) that absorb the heat Q. Since the process occurs at constant temperature T = 300 K, the entropy increase of the reservoir is

  ΔS_reservoir = Q/T = (3.0 × 10⁶ J)/(300 K) = 10,000 J/K.

Since the resistor’s entropy change is zero, the total change in the entropy of the universe (resistor + reservoir) is

  ΔS_universe = ΔS_resistor + ΔS_reservoir = 0 + 10,000 J/K = 10,000 J/K.
 
─────────────────────────────  
Step 3: Change in the Internal Energy of the Universe (c)

The resistor is kept at constant temperature, implying that its internal energy does not change (ΔU_resistor = 0). The reservoir is assumed to be so large that absorbing the heat Q does not change its internal energy appreciably or its state. (Alternatively, if we include the electrical energy supplied to the resistor, then energy conservation tells us that the electrical work is entirely converted into heat which is then transferred to the reservoir; thus, for the resistor–reservoir system the increase in internal energy is zero.) Therefore, we have

  ΔU_universe = 0.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 4: Change in the Helmholtz Free Energy of the Universe (d)

The Helmholtz free energy is defined as F = U – TS. For a process at constant temperature, the change in free energy is given by

  ΔF_universe = ΔU_universe – T ΔS_universe.

Since we found ΔU_universe = 0 and ΔS_universe = 10,000 J/K, it follows that

  ΔF_universe = 0 – (300 K)(10,000 J/K) = –3.0 × 10⁶ J.

─────────────────────────────  
Summary of Answers:

(a) The change in the entropy of the resistor is 0.  
(b) The change in the entropy of the universe is 10,000 J/K.  
(c) The change in the internal energy of the universe is 0.  
(d) The change in the Helmholtz free energy of the universe is –3.0 × 10⁶ J.

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&(a)\quad \Delta S_{\text{resistor}} = 0, \\
&(b)\quad \Delta S_{\text{universe}} = 10{,}000\ \mathrm{J/K}, \\
&(c)\quad \Delta U_{\text{universe}} = 0, \\
&(d)\quad \Delta F_{\text{universe}} = -3.0 \times 10^6\ \mathrm{J}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to analyze the Van der Waals equation

  ( p + a/V² )(V – b) = RT      (1)

for one mole of gas. We will answer each part in turn.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Sketching Isotherms and Identifying the Critical Point

If we write p explicitly, we have

  p = [RT/(V – b)] – a/V².     (2)

When one plots p versus V for constant T (isotherms), the curves display the following features:
 • For high T the curves look similar to those for an ideal gas but shifted.
 • For temperatures below a critical temperature T_c the isotherms exhibit an “S-shaped” curve with a region of positive slope (∂p/∂V > 0) which is unstable.
 • The critical isotherm is the one for which the inflection point appears. That is, at the critical point we have
   (∂p/∂V)_T = 0   and  (∂²p/∂V²)_T = 0.
A standard analysis of Eq. (2) gives

  V_c = 3b,
  T_c = 8a/(27Rb),
  p_c = a/(27b²).

On a p–V diagram (with V horizontal and p vertical) one draws curves corresponding to T > T_c, T = T_c, and T < T_c. The T < T_c curves show an unphysical S–shaped region. The point (V_c, p_c, T_c) is the critical point.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Evaluating the Dimensionless Ratio pV/RT at the Critical Point

We wish to compute

  (pV/RT)_{critical} = (p_c V_c)/(R T_c).

Using the critical values found above:
 • p_c = a/(27b²),
 • V_c = 3b,
 • T_c = 8a/(27Rb).

First, compute p_c V_c:
  p_c V_c = [a/(27b²)] (3b) = 3a/(27b) = a/(9b).

Also, RT_c = R[8a/(27Rb)] = 8a/(27b).

Now, the ratio is

  (p_c V_c)/(R T_c) = (a/(9b)) / (8a/(27b))
           = (a/(9b)) × (27b/(8a))
           = (27)/(9×8) = 27/72 = 3/8.

Thus, at the critical point, the dimensionless ratio is 3/8.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Maxwell’s Construction and the Modified Isotherm

For T < T_c the S–shaped Van der Waals isotherm (from Eq. (2)) has regions in which (∂p/∂V)_T > 0. Such behavior is unphysical because it would correspond to a negative compressibility. In a real substance, during a phase change (liquid and vapor coexist), the pressure remains constant as the volume changes. Maxwell’s idea was to replace the S–shaped part of the isotherm by a horizontal line (constant pressure p₀) which connects the two volumes where the gas and liquid phases coexist.

Maxwell required that the “area of the loop” above the horizontal line be exactly equal to the area of the “dip” below it. Mathematically, if V₁ and V₂ are the endpoints (volumes) of the horizontal section, then one must have

  ∫₍V₁₎^(V₂) [p(V) – p₀] dV = 0.

This construction guarantees that the Gibbs free energy (which is found by an integral of the pressure with respect to volume) is the same for both phases, ensuring phase equilibrium. In a diagram one would show the original van der Waals curve, then replace the unstable portion by a horizontal line at p₀; the areas above and below this line between V₁ and V₂ (as determined by the van der Waals curve) are equal.

──────────────────────────────
Step (d): Showing that C_V Is a Function of Temperature Alone

For any substance the internal energy U may in general depend on both temperature T and volume V, i.e., U = U(T,V). However, for a Van der Waals gas the “nonideal” corrections are assumed not to contribute to the dependence of U on temperature. In other words, the temperature dependence comes solely from the kinetic (ideal gas) part of the energy. A thermodynamic relation (derived from the fundamental thermodynamic identity) is

  (∂U/∂V)_T = T (∂p/∂T)_V – p.    (3)

For the van der Waals gas,
  p = [RT/(V – b)] – a/V².
Then

  (∂p/∂T)_V = R/(V – b).

So,
  (∂U/∂V)_T = T[R/(V – b)] – [RT/(V – b) – a/V²]
           = (TR/(V – b)) – (RT/(V – b)) + a/V²
           = a/V².

Thus the change of internal energy with volume at fixed T is given solely by a term a/V², which comes from the intermolecular attraction. Importantly, when we calculate the heat capacity at constant volume

  C_V = (∂U/∂T)_V,
any explicit V–dependence from the potential energy term does not occur because the a/V term in U does not depend on T. In other words, the temperature derivative (∂U/∂T)_V is the same as that of an ideal gas. Therefore, for a Van der Waals gas, C_V is a function of T only and is independent of V.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

 (a) The Van der Waals isotherms in the p–V plane show an S–shape for T < T_c, with the critical point given by V_c = 3b, T_c = 8a/(27Rb), and p_c = a/(27b²).  
 (b) At the critical point, p_cV_c/(RT_c) = 3/8.  
 (c) Maxwell’s construction replaces the unphysical portion of the isotherm by a horizontal line (at pressure p₀) determined by requiring equal areas above and below the line between the coexistence volumes; this ensures equal Gibbs free energies for the two phases.  
 (d) Since for a Van der Waals gas the only T–dependent part of the internal energy is the same as that for an ideal gas, the constant–volume heat capacity, C_V = (∂U/∂T)_V, depends only on T and not on V.

 Thus, the final answers are

  \[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & V_c=3b,\quad T_c=\frac{8a}{27Rb},\quad p_c=\frac{a}{27b^2};\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & \frac{p_cV_c}{RT_c}=\frac{3}{8};\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & \text{Maxwell's construction replaces the unstable S–shaped portion with a horizontal tie–line at } p_0 
\\[2mm]
& \quad \text{such that } \int_{V_1}^{V_2}(p(V)-p_0)\,dV=0\text{, thereby ensuring equal Gibbs free energies.}\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad & C_V=\left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial T}\right)_V\text{ is independent of }V \text{ (as for an ideal gas).}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to “name‐real” systems (or families of systems) for which the indicated thermodynamic “derivatives” assume the stated values. (In all of the answers we restrict ourselves to a single‐component, classical, chemical system of fixed mass.) In what follows we occasionally remind you that many of the relations below can be derived from the fundamental equation

  dU = T dS – p dV

and from the Maxwell relation

  (∂S/∂V)_T = (∂p/∂T)_V.

Below is one acceptable set of answers.

─────────────────────────────

Step (a). Condition 
  (∂U/∂V)_T = 0.

Recall that in many systems the internal energy U is a function of both T and V. However, for the ideal gas the electromagnetic (or intermolecular potential) interactions are absent so that U depends only on temperature. (Of course in an ideal gas the only contribution to U is kinetic, and the kinetic energy depends only on T.) Thus for an ideal gas,
  U = U(T)
and therefore
  (∂U/∂V)_T = 0.
Thus one acceptable answer is: an ideal gas (or a gas sufficiently dilute that intermolecular forces may be neglected).

─────────────────────────────

Step (b). Condition 
  (∂S/∂V)_p < 0.

At first sight one might expect that, at fixed pressure, increasing volume increases the number of accessible configurations and hence the entropy. (Indeed, for the ideal gas one finds, using the equation of state, that S increases with V at fixed p.) Thus, for “normal” substances one normally has (∂S/∂V)_p > 0. In order for the derivative to be negative one must have a substance whose response is “anomalous” – so that when the system is forced to expand at constant p it must “order” rather than disorder. (One finds that upon expansion the temperature must drop so much that the loss in thermal disorder outweighs the extra positional disorder.) An example of such anomalous behavior occurs in water. (See, for example, the discussion of density anomalies in water.) When water is near its temperature of maximum density (near 4°C at 1 atm) a volume increase (at fixed pressure) is accompanied by a reorganization of the hydrogen–bond network that leads to a net decrease in the entropy. (One may say that the system “orders” more as its local structure becomes more tetrahedral.) Thus a possible answer is: a liquid (such as water under conditions near its density maximum) for which the anomalous thermal – expansion properties lead to (∂S/∂V)_p < 0.

─────────────────────────────

Step (c). Condition 
  (∂T/∂S)_p = 0.

In words, at constant pressure an increase in the entropy does not change the temperature. This is precisely what happens during a first–order phase transition (at fixed pressure) when latent heat is absorbed (or released) at a constant temperature. (For instance, as ice melts or water boils at 1 atm the temperature stays fixed while the entropy changes discontinuously.) Thus one acceptable answer is: a system undergoing a first–order phase transition (say, boiling water at 1 atm) exhibits (∂T/∂S)_p = 0 during the coexistence interval.

─────────────────────────────

Step (d). Condition 
  (∂S/∂V)_T = 0.

There is a useful Maxwell relation,
  (∂S/∂V)_T = (∂p/∂T)_V.
Thus the condition (∂S/∂V)_T = 0 is equivalent to (∂p/∂T)_V = 0. In words, at fixed volume the pressure is independent of temperature. This is not a property of, say, an ideal gas (for which p ∝ T), but it is the characteristic of a system whose “configurational” (or potential‐energy) part does not “feel” the temperature. One may think of a system in which the only T–dependent contribution to the entropy is “decoupled” from the volume. (For instance, many nearly “incompressible” solids have vibrational densities of state that change only very weakly with volume. In a crude approximate description the entropy at fixed temperature may then be nearly independent of V.) Thus an acceptable answer is: a nearly incompressible solid (or any system with an “athermal” equation of state so that (∂p/∂T)_V ≈ 0) will have (∂S/∂V)_T = 0.

─────────────────────────────

Step (e). Condition 
  (∂T/∂V)_S = - (∂p/∂S)_V.

One may show (by taking the appropriate second derivatives of U(S,V)) that the equality
  (∂T/∂V)_S = - (∂p/∂S)_V
is in fact an automatic consequence of the fundamental thermodynamic relation. In other words, it is nothing other than a Maxwell relation that holds for any system (in which U is a state function of S and V). Thus an acceptable answer is: every classical, single–component, fixed–mass chemical system (with a well–defined U(S,V)) satisfies this relation.

─────────────────────────────

Thus, one acceptable complete answer is as follows:

(a) An ideal gas (for which the internal energy is a function only of T) satisfies (∂U/∂V)_T = 0.

(b) A liquid with anomalous thermal–expansion – for example, water near the temperature of its density maximum – will have (∂S/∂V)_p < 0 (since expansion at fixed p then “orders” the system).

(c) A system undergoing a first–order phase transition (e.g. boiling water at 1 atm, or melting ice) has (∂T/∂S)_p = 0, since T remains constant while heat is absorbed (latent heat).

(d) A nearly incompressible solid (or any system with an “athermal” pressure so that (∂p/∂T)_V ≈ 0) has (∂S/∂V)_T = 0.

(e) The relation (∂T/∂V)_S = – (∂p/∂S)_V is a Maxwell relation and thus holds in all thermodynamically consistent classical, single–component, fixed–mass chemical systems.

─────────────────────────────

Final Answer in Latex Boxed Format:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{rcl}
(a) &:& \text{An ideal gas, for which } U=U(T) \text{ and } \left(\frac{\partial U}{\partial V}\right)_T=0.\\[1mm]
(b) &:& \text{A liquid with anomalous thermal--expansion (e.g. water near its density maximum), so that}\\[1mm]
&& \left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial V}\right)_p< 0.\\[1mm]
(c) &:& \text{A system undergoing a first--order phase transition (e.g. boiling water), in which } T \text{ is constant as } S \text{ changes,}\\[1mm]
&& \text{thus } \left(\frac{\partial T}{\partial S}\right)_p=0.\\[1mm]
(d) &:& \text{A nearly incompressible solid (or other system for which } (\partial p/\partial T)_V\approx 0\text{), so that}\\[1mm]
&& \left(\frac{\partial S}{\partial V}\right)_T=0.\\[1mm]
(e) &:& \text{This is exactly a Maxwell relation, valid for any thermodynamically consistent system.}
\end{array}
}
\]
