We wish to understand how the “color‐composition” changes over time when bacteria occasionally reproduce but the total number is kept fixed by “predation”. In our setting the two “alleles” (red and green markers) are completely neutral (apart from the colors) so that there is no difference in reproduction. (In part (c) we break this neutrality slightly.) In effect, one has a fixed‐size population (10,000 bacteria) in which at every “time‐step” one bacterium reproduces (splitting into two of its own type) and one bacterium is removed (killed by the predator). (The predator does its choice at random.) This is exactly the structure of the celebrated Moran process in population genetics.

Below we explain step‐by‐step the answers.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. (The Neutral Case) What is the equilibrium (long‐time) distribution?

In a finite neutral Moran process (i.e. one with no mutation or migration) the only absorbing states are those in which the entire population is fixed for one type. Starting with 5,000 red and 5,000 green bacteria the process then “wanders” (by random genetic drift) until eventually one of the two types is eliminated. Thus, after a “very long time” the only possible outcomes are

 • all bacteria are red (i.e. 10,000 red, 0 green) or
 • all bacteria are green (i.e. 0 red, 10,000 green).

Since every reproduction–death event is completely “fair” (no bias) the probability that red eventually fixes is just its initial frequency, namely 5000/10000 = 1/2 (and green fixes with probability 1/2).

Thus, (a) in the neutral case the distribution of the number of red bacteria is given by
  P{red = 10,000} = 1/2  and  P{red = 0} = 1/2,
with all intermediate states having probability 0 in the long‐time limit.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. (Time to fixation when neutral)

Next, we ask: how long will one have to “wait” (i.e. how many reproduction–death events must occur) before the system is essentially fixed in one of the two states?

The Moran process is well‐studied. For a neutral process (i.e. no selection), a standard result for the mean time (in number of events) to absorption is

  Tᵢ = –2N [(i/N) ln(i/N) + (1 – i/N) ln(1 – i/N)]
     (see, e.g., Ewens, “Mathematical Population Genetics”)

Here N = 10,000 and the initial number of red is i = 5000, so that i/N = 0.5. Then
  T₅₀₀₀ = –2·10,000 [0.5 ln(0.5) + 0.5 ln(0.5)]
        = –20,000 [ln(0.5)]
        = 20,000 · ln2    (since ln(0.5) = –ln2).

Numerically, 
  20,000 · ln2 ≈ 20,000 × 0.693 ≈ 13,860 hours.

Since in our setting each update occurs every hour, the expected time to fixation is about 13,860 hours – which is roughly 575–600 days (roughly a year and a half).

Thus, (b) you must wait on the order of 14,000 hours (nearly 600 days) before the colony almost surely consists of only one color.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. (The Slightly Biased Case)

Now, suppose the predator has a 1% preference for red bacteria. (In words, the predator is 1% more likely to eat a red bacterium than a green one.)

Let us be precise. At every time‐step the following occurs:
 (1) A bacterium is chosen uniformly at random to reproduce.
 (2) One bacterium is chosen to be eaten. In the unbiased case every bacterium had the same chance (1/10,000) of being eaten. Now, however, if there are x red bacteria and 10,000 – x green bacteria, we assume that each red bacterium has weight 1.01 and each green bacterium weight 1, so that the total weight is

  W = 1.01·x + 1·(10,000 – x).

Thus the probability that a red bacterium is eaten is

  P(red eaten) = (1.01·x) / (10,000 + 0.01·x).

Likewise, the probability that a green bacterium is eaten is

  P(green eaten) = (10,000 – x) / (10,000 + 0.01·x).

Now, let us describe the possible “steps” that change the number x of red bacteria. (Recall that if a red bacterium reproduces and a green dies, then x increases by 1; if a green reproduces and a red dies, then x decreases by 1; if both reproduction and death occur in the same color then x doesn’t change.)

The probability that x increases by 1 is:
  P(x → x + 1) = (chance a red reproduces) × (chance a green is eaten)
         = (x/10,000) · ((10,000 – x)/(10,000 + 0.01·x)).

Similarly, the probability that x decreases by 1 is:
  P(x → x – 1) = (chance a green reproduces) × (chance a red is eaten)
         = ((10,000 – x)/10,000) · ((1.01·x)/(10,000 + 0.01·x)).

Thus, the “drift” (or mean change) per time‐step is proportional to

  Δx ∝ (x(10,000 – x)) [1 – 1.01] = –0.01 · x(10,000 – x),
indicating that red bacteria suffer a disadvantage equivalent to a selection coefficient of roughly 1%.

The standard result for the fixation probability u(i) of a deleterious allele in a Moran process (starting with i individuals in a total population of size N) is

  u(i) = (1 – e^(–s·i)) / (1 – e^(–s·N))
        (for any s, with s > 0 meaning an advantage).

Here red is at a disadvantage, so we take s = 0.01 but note that its “advantage” is –s. (One may simply plug in –0.01 for s into the above formula.) Starting from i = 5000,
  u(5000) = (1 – e^(+0.01·5000))/(1 – e^(+0.01·10000)) 
        = (1 – e^(50))/(1 – e^(100)).

Now, e^(50) and e^(100) are enormous numbers. In fact, both numerator and denominator are negative (since 1 – e^(50) < 0, etc.) but the ratio is positive. For large numbers, we can “invert” the formula to see that this ratio is extremely small – roughly of order e^(-50) ≈ 2×10^(–22). In words, starting at a 50–50 mix, almost certainly eventually the red bacteria will be eliminated.

The selection (bias) also speeds up the process. In a Moran process with selection the typical time scale is shorter than in the neutral case. Rough estimates (or standard theory) tell us that the typical time scale for fixation under selection is of order

  T ~ (ln N)/|s|.

For N = 10,000 and |s| = 0.01 this gives

  T ~ (ln 10,000)/0.01 ≈ (9.21)/(0.01) ≈ 921 hours,

which is roughly 38 days. (The exact factor depends on the precise details of the process, but this is the correct order‐of‐magnitude.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) In the unbiased (“neutral”) case the only absorbing states are 0 red (all green) and 10,000 red (all red). Because the process is neutral, the probability of each is given by the initial frequency; that is, there is a 50% chance that eventually all bacteria are red and a 50% chance they are all green.

(b) In the neutral case the expected time until one color “fixes” is roughly 2N ln2 ≈ 14,000 hours (or about 600 days).

(c) With a 1% bias (red bacteria are 1% more likely to be eaten) the process is no longer neutral. In that case red almost surely eventually goes extinct (with a fixation probability of roughly 2×10^(–22)) and the time to fixation is much shorter – approximately (ln 10,000)/0.01 ≈ 921 hours (around 38 days).

──────────────────────────────
Final boxed answer

\[
\boxed{\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad&\text{In the neutral case, eventually }P\{R=0\}=0.5\text{ and }P\{R=10,\!000\}=0.5,\,P\{R=k\}=0\text{ for }0<k<10,\!000.\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad&\text{The mean time to fixation is about }2\cdot10,\!000\ln2\approx14,\!000\text{ hours (nearly 600 days).}\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad&\text{If the predator has a 1\% preference for red, red’s effective fitness is reduced by about 1\%;}\\
&\text{thus, almost surely (with probability } \sim1\text{) red is eliminated, and the mean time to fixation}\\
&\text{drops to roughly } \ln(10,\!000)/0.01\approx920\text{ hours (about 38 days).}
\end{aligned}}
\]

The Carnot cycle is an idealized thermodynamic cycle that represents the most efficient engine possible operating between two heat reservoirs. It consists of four reversible processes:

1. Isothermal Expansion (at temperature Tₕ): The system expands while absorbing heat Qₕ from a high-temperature reservoir. During this step, the temperature remains constant and the system does work on the surroundings.
2. Adiabatic Expansion: The system continues to expand without any heat exchange (Q = 0), causing its temperature to drop from Tₕ to T𝒸.
3. Isothermal Compression (at temperature T𝒸): The system is compressed while releasing heat Q𝒸 to a low-temperature reservoir. The temperature remains constant during this compression.
4. Adiabatic Compression: The system is compressed further without heat exchange, raising its temperature from T𝒸 back to Tₕ.

Let’s break down these steps, illustrate them on both pV and ST diagrams, and then derive the efficiency.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 1. Illustrating the Cycle

A. pV Diagram

On a pressure–volume (pV) diagram, the Carnot cycle appears as a closed loop consisting of:

• Process AB (Isothermal Expansion at Tₕ): The curve represents an isotherm; as the system expands (increase in volume), the pressure decreases.
• Process BC (Adiabatic Expansion): The curve drops more steeply because no heat is exchanged. Here the system’s temperature drops from Tₕ to T𝒸.
• Process CD (Isothermal Compression at T𝒸): This is another isotherm where volume decreases; the pressure increases as the system rejects heat.
• Process DA (Adiabatic Compression): The process takes the system back to the original state (Tₕ) with no heat exchange. The pressure increases further while the volume decreases.

Imagine the loop starting at point A, moving along AB (isotherm at Tₕ), then BC (adiabat), then CD (isotherm at T𝒸), and then DA (adiabat) back to A.

B. ST Diagram

The entropy–temperature (ST) diagram is particularly useful for reversible cycles:
 
• For the isothermal processes, temperature is constant while entropy changes. 
  - During AB, the system absorbs heat Qₕ, so the entropy increases by ΔS = Qₕ/Tₕ.
  - During CD, the system rejects heat Q𝒸, so the entropy decreases by ΔS = Q𝒸/T𝒸.
• For the adiabatic processes (BC and DA), no heat is exchanged, so the entropy remains constant.

Thus, the ST diagram shows two horizontal lines corresponding to the isothermal steps (one at Tₕ with an area representing Qₕ, and one at T𝒸 representing Q𝒸) connected by vertical lines (adiabats) where entropy is unchanged.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 2. Deriving the Efficiency

The efficiency (η) of any engine is given by the net work output divided by the heat input at the high temperature:

  η = 1 – (Q𝒸 / Qₕ).

For the Carnot cycle, the only heat exchanges occur during the isothermal steps.

• During the isothermal expansion (at Tₕ):
  Qₕ = Tₕ ΔS,
  where ΔS is the change in entropy during expansion.

• During the isothermal compression (at T𝒸):
  Q𝒸 = T𝒸 ΔS,
  (here ΔS is the same magnitude, but the heat is rejected, so sometimes it is denoted with a negative sign—the absolute values are used in efficiency calculations).

Thus, substituting these into the efficiency formula:

  η = 1 – (T𝒸 ΔS / Tₕ ΔS) = 1 – (T𝒸 / Tₕ).

This result shows that the efficiency of a Carnot engine depends solely on the temperatures of the high and low reservoirs.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer

The Carnot cycle is an idealized cycle composed of two isothermal and two adiabatic processes. On a pV diagram, it appears as a closed loop with isothermal curves at high and low temperatures connected by adiabatic curves. On an ST diagram, it appears as a horizontal expansion (increase in entropy) at Tₕ, a vertical (adiabatic) drop, a horizontal compression (decrease in entropy) at T𝒸, and another vertical (adiabatic) rise. The efficiency of a Carnot engine operating between a high temperature Tₕ and a low temperature T𝒸 is derived as:

  η = 1 – (T𝒸 / Tₕ).

\[
\boxed{\eta = 1 -\frac{T_\text{C}}{T_\text{H}}}
\]

We are given a “drunk” who starts at the origin (the lamp‐post) and takes 3 steps. At each step he randomly picks one of the four directions: north, south, east, or west. Each step is of fixed length L. We wish to determine the probability that after 3 steps he ends up within a circle of radius 2L (i.e. with distance ≤2L from the origin).

Step 1. Restate the problem in rescaled units

It is convenient to work in units of L (i.e. set L = 1 for the counting) so that the condition becomes “within a circle of radius 2” (distance ≤2).

Step 2. Describe the steps

In each step the drunk moves one unit in one of the four cardinal directions. Thus, each step changes either the x–coordinate or the y–coordinate by ±1. After 3 steps his final position is determined by the sums
  x = (number of east steps) – (number of west steps)
  y = (number of north steps) – (number of south steps)
with the constraint that the total number of steps is 3. In every step a move is made so exactly one coordinate changes.

Step 3. List the possible splits of moves

Every 3-step path can be divided into moves that affect x and moves that affect y. The only possibilities (since the number of moves must add to 3) are:
  (a) 3 moves in one coordinate (and 0 in the other) or
  (b) 2 moves along one coordinate and 1 move along the other.

Notice that (a) gives all moves along either x or y, while (b) involves moves in both coordinates.

Step 4. Determine the final displacements and distances

Let us look at these cases:

Case (a): All 3 moves in one coordinate.
 • If all 3 are in the x–direction then possible outcomes are:
  (3, 0) if all are east, or (–3, 0) if all are west.
 • If all 3 are in the y–direction then possible outcomes are:
  (0, 3) or (0, –3).

In each case the distance from the origin is |3| = 3 which is greater than 2. So none of these 4 outcomes is allowed.

Case (b): Two moves in one coordinate and one in the other.
There are two subcases:

Subcase 1: 2 moves in x and 1 move in y.
 – The two x–moves can result in:
  • x = 2 if both are east (or –2 if both are west).
  • x = 0 if one is east and one is west.
 – The single y–move can be either north (y = 1) or south (y = –1).

Thus the possible outcomes are:
  (a) (2, 1), (2, –1), (–2, 1), (–2, –1) and
  (b) (0, 1), (0, –1).

Now check their distances:
 • For (2, ±1): Distance² = 2² + 1² = 4 + 1 = 5, so distance = √5 > 2.
 • For (0, ±1): Distance² = 0 + 1 = 1, which is within 2.

Subcase 2: 1 move in x and 2 moves in y.
 – The single x–move is either east (x = 1) or west (x = –1).
 – The two y–moves can result in:
  • y = 2 if both are north (or –2 if both are south),
  • y = 0 if one is north and one is south.

Possible outcomes:
  (a) (1, 2), (–1, 2), (1, –2), (–1, –2) and
  (b) (1, 0), (–1, 0).

Distances:
 • For (±1, 2) and (±1, –2): Distance² = 1 + 4 = 5, so √5 > 2.
 • For (1,0) and (–1,0): Distance² = 1 which is allowed.

Thus, the only allowed final displacements (with Euclidean distance ≤ 2) are:
  (0, 1), (0, –1), (1, 0), and (–1, 0).

Step 5. Count the number of paths (outcomes) leading to these allowed displacements

Total outcomes over 3 steps = 4^3 = 64.

We now count the number of distinct 3‐step paths that yield each allowed endpoint.

a. Paths yielding (0, 1)

How can we get (0, 1)? We need the y–coordinate to be +1 and the x–coordinate to be 0.
 Notice that 0 can only be obtained as a sum when there are two moves in that coordinate with one step east and one west. So the 0 in x forces the scenario where there are 2 moves in x (one east and one west) and 1 move in y. (It is impossible to have a net 0 from a single move.)
 – Choose 2 out of the 3 steps to be the x–moves: this can be done in C(3,2) = 3 ways.
 – For the 2 x–moves, to have net 0 we must have one east and one west. There are 2 orders in which this can happen.
 – The one y–move (which happens in the remaining step) must be north (to give y = +1). There is only 1 possibility.
Thus the number of paths giving (0, 1) is: 3 × 2 × 1 = 6.

b. Similarly, (0, –1) is obtained by the same reasoning (with the y–move being south): 6 paths.

c. For (1, 0)

Here we need x = +1 and y = 0. To have y = 0, we must have 2 y–moves that cancel (one north and one south), so the 2 y–moves yield net 0.
 – Choose 1 out of 3 steps to be the x–move: C(3,1) = 3 ways.
 – The single x–move must be east (to get +1): 1 possibility.
 – The 2 y–moves must consist of one north and one south. There are 2 orders for these moves.
Thus the number of paths for (1, 0) is: 3 × 1 × 2 = 6.

d. Likewise, (–1, 0) has 6 paths.

Total allowed paths = 6 + 6 + 6 + 6 = 24.

Step 6. Compute the probability

Probability = (Number of allowed outcomes) / (Total outcomes) = 24 / 64 = 3/8.

Final Answer:

\[\boxed{\frac{3}{8}}\]

We will address each part in turn.

────────────────────────
Step (a): Fundamental Assumptions

• Maxwell–Boltzmann (MB) statistics assumes that the particles are classical and – even if they may be identical in mass and charge – they are taken as distinguishable. No restrictions are imposed on the number of particles per quantum state. In MB theory the probability of finding a particle in a state of energy E is proportional to exp(–E/kT) and there is no account taken of quantum exchange effects.

• Fermi–Dirac (FD) statistics is designed for quantum particles of half–integer spin (fermions) that obey the Pauli exclusion principle; that is, no two fermions can occupy the same quantum state. Accordingly, the FD factor for the occupation of an energy level is 1/(e^( (E–μ)/kT ) + 1). It is based on the indistinguishability of particles and the antisymmetrization of their many–body wavefunctions.

────────────────────────
Step (b): Energy Distribution Plots

For a system of free particles the MB energy distribution goes as f_MB(E) ∝ exp(–E/kT). Consider two temperatures: at a higher temperature the decay with energy is slower (i.e. the distribution is broader) compared with the lower temperature.

For FD statistics the energy distribution is given roughly by:
  f_FD(E)= 1/ (e^( (E–μ)/kT) + 1).
At absolute zero the FD distribution is a step function (with a sharp cutoff at the Fermi energy, μ = E_F). At finite temperatures the step is smeared over an energy range ~ kT. Thus, in a rough sketch:

1. MB curves: Plot two curves that fall exponentially. The higher–temperature MB curve falls off more slowly (i.e. is “stretched out” to higher energies) than the lower–temperature one.
2. FD curves: At a lower temperature the FD curve is nearly a perfect step function (f ≈1 for E < E_F and nearly zero for E > E_F). At a higher temperature the curve shows a softening of the step – a smoother transition around E_F.

When indicating which curve corresponds to the higher temperature, keep in mind that for MB the higher T curve is broader. For FD, the higher temperature curve shows a greater “rounding” of the step in the transition region near the Fermi energy.

────────────────────────
Step (c): Specific Heat of Metals

The classical prediction using MB statistics leads to a specific heat contribution from electrons that is far too large compared with experimental measurements. In the MB picture nearly all electrons can be thermally excited. However, experiments show that the electronic contribution to the specific heat of metals is only a small fraction of that predicted by MB statistics.

FD statistics resolves this discrepancy. Since fermions obey the Pauli exclusion principle, at low temperatures only electrons within an energy band of order kT (around the Fermi energy) are available for excitation. The vast majority of electrons are “frozen” into filled states and do not contribute to the specific heat. Therefore, the FD theory naturally predicts a much smaller electronic specific heat, in agreement with experiment.

────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{(a)}\quad & \text{MB statistics assumes classical, distinguishable particles with no restrictions on state occupancy,} \\
& \text{leading to an exponential factor, } e^{-E/kT}. \ \text{In contrast, FD statistics applies to indistinguishable fermions } \\
& \text{which obey the Pauli exclusion principle (each state may be occupied by at most one particle), giving} \\
& \text{an occupancy factor of } \frac{1}{e^{(E-\mu)/kT}+1}. \\[1mm]
\textbf{(b)}\quad & \text{For MB, the energy distribution curves (∝} \, e^{-E/kT}\text{) at higher T are broader (i.e. decay slower) than at lower T.} \\
& \text{For FD, at very low T the distribution is a near step function (1 for } E<E_F \text{ and 0 for } E>E_F\text{),} \\
& \text{while at higher T the step is smeared out. The broader MB curve and the more smeared FD step} \\
& \text{correspond to the higher temperature.} \\[1mm]
\textbf{(c)}\quad & \text{MB statistics over–estimates the electronic specific heat in metals because it assumes most electrons can} \\

& \sim kT \text{) can be excited. FD statistics correctly accounts for this, leading to a much smaller electronic specific} \\
& \text{heat in agreement with experimental observations.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We begin by noting that the formation of ice requires the removal of latent heat. Since the ice has a thickness h(t) at time t, heat is conducted from the water/ice interface (at 0°C) through the ice layer to the cold air. The steady conduction flux (energy per unit area per unit time) through the ice is given by Fourier’s law:

  Q = Λ (ΔT / h)

where Λ is the thermal conductivity of the ice and ΔT is the temperature difference between the ice/water interface and the cold air.

This conducted heat is used to freeze more water. The latent heat per unit volume needed to freeze water is L/V. When a thin slice of ice of thickness dh forms over a time dt, the energy required per unit area is (L/V) dh.

Since the rate at which latent heat is “removed” (by conduction) must balance the latent heat needed to freeze an incremental thickness, we equate the conduction flux to the energy rate used for freezing:

  Λ (ΔT / h) = (L/V) (dh/dt)

Solve for dh/dt:

  dh/dt = [Λ ΔT / h] / (L/V) = (Λ ΔT) / ((L/V) h)

Separate variables:

  h dh = (Λ ΔT/(L/V)) dt

Integrate both sides; taking h = 0 at t = 0:

  ∫₀^(h(t)) h dh = ∫₀^(t) (Λ ΔT/(L/V)) dt

The integration yields:

  ½ [h(t)]² = (Λ ΔT/(L/V)) t

Solve for h(t):

  h(t) = √[ (2 Λ ΔT t)/(L/V) ]

Thus, the thickness of the ice as a function of time is given by:

  h(t) = √[ (2 Λ ΔT t)/(L/V) ]

Final Answer:

  \[\boxed{h(t) = \sqrt{\frac{2\Lambda \Delta T\, t}{L/V}}}\]

We wish to describe a system in which each of the N particles can be in one of two energy levels: E₀ or E₁. In what follows we will assume that the particles are “classical” in the sense that their occupation is given by the Boltzmann weight. (In many texts the two‐level system is taken as “quantum” with non‐degenerate levels but the occupation factors are still given by Boltzmann factors. In any event, we assume here that the probabilities of occupation are proportional to e^(–βE) with β = 1/(kT).) For convenience it is sometimes useful to define

  Δ = E₁ – E₀   (with Δ > 0)

and even to set the zero of energy at E₀, so that E₀ = 0 and E₁ = Δ. (We will give answers in a form that is valid in general.)

Let us now answer each part.

────────────────────────
Step (a): Average Energy per Particle

Each particle has probability
  p₀ = e^(–βE₀) / Z  and  p₁ = e^(–βE₁) / Z,
where the single–particle partition function is
  Z = e^(–βE₀) + e^(–βE₁).

Thus the average energy per particle is
  ⟨E⟩ = E₀·p₀ + E₁·p₁
    = (E₀e^(–βE₀) + E₁e^(–βE₁)) / (e^(–βE₀) + e^(–βE₁)).

An equivalent form is obtained by factoring out e^(–βE₀):
  ⟨E⟩ = E₀ + (E₁ – E₀)·(e^(–βE₁)/ (e^(–βE₀) + e^(–βE₁)))
    = E₀ + (E₁ – E₀)·(e^(–βΔ) / (1 + e^(–βΔ))).
Alternatively, one may write this as

  ⟨E⟩ = E₀ + (E₁ – E₀) / (e^(βΔ) + 1).

This is our answer for part (a).

────────────────────────
Step (b): Asymptotic Behavior of ⟨E⟩

It is often illuminating to see the behavior in the low and high temperature limits.

1. As T → 0 (i.e. β → ∞):  
Since Δ > 0, we have e^(–βΔ) → 0. Then
  ⟨E⟩ → E₀ + (E₁ – E₀)·0/(1+0) = E₀.
Physically, at very low temperature the particles “fall” into the lower energy state E₀.

2. As T → ∞ (i.e. β → 0):  
Now e^(–βΔ) → 1, so
  ⟨E⟩ → E₀ + (E₁ – E₀)/(1+1)
        = E₀ + ½(E₁ – E₀)
        = (E₀ + E₁)/2.
Thus at high temperature the two states become equally populated.

────────────────────────
Step (c): Specific Heat of the System

The specific heat (at constant volume, equivalently, since there is no volume change here) is defined as

  C = dU/dT,

where U = N ⟨E⟩ is the total internal energy. Thus we may write the specific heat per particle as
  c = d⟨E⟩/dT,
and the total specific heat is C = N·c.

A very convenient alternative (equivalent) expression is given by the energy fluctuation formula:
  c = (1/(kT²)) (⟨E²⟩ – ⟨E⟩²).
For a two-level system the variance is easily computed. (However, one may also differentiate the expression for ⟨E⟩ with respect to T.)

For clarity we now “set the zero” at E₀ = 0 (i.e. measure energies from E₀) so that E₁ = Δ. In that case the partition function becomes

  Z = 1 + e^(–βΔ),
and the average energy per particle is
  ⟨E⟩ = Δ (e^(–βΔ))/(1 + e^(–βΔ)).

The probability to be in the excited state is
  p = e^(–βΔ)/(1 + e^(–βΔ)),
so that the variance is
  ⟨(δE)²⟩ = p (1 – p) Δ².

Thus the specific heat per particle is
  c = (1/(kT²)) [Δ² p (1 – p)]
    = (Δ²/(kT²))· [e^(–βΔ)/(1 + e^(–βΔ))²].
For N particles the total specific heat is

  C = N (Δ²/(kT²))· [e^(–βΔ)/(1 + e^(–βΔ))²].

It is often rewritten in the form

  C = N k (βΔ)²· [e^(–βΔ)/(1 + e^(–βΔ))²].

This is our answer for part (c).

────────────────────────
Step (d): Asymptotic Behavior of the Specific Heat

Now we examine two limits.

1. As T → 0 (β → ∞):  
In this limit, e^(–βΔ) tends to 0 very rapidly. Hence, even though (βΔ)² becomes large, the numerator e^(–βΔ) makes the whole expression vanish. Thus, we obtain

  C → 0  as T → 0.

2. As T → ∞ (β → 0):  
In the high–temperature limit, e^(–βΔ) → 1 so that
  C ≈ N k (βΔ)² [1/(1+1)²] = N k (βΔ)²/4.
But since β = 1/(kT), we have (βΔ)² = Δ²/(k²T²). Thus,
  C ≈ N (Δ²/(4kT²)).
Hence, as T → ∞, C → 0 because of the factor 1/T².

Thus, the specific heat has a “Schottky anomaly” – it reaches a maximum at a temperature on the order of Δ/k and then vanishes as T → 0 and T → ∞.

────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The average energy per particle is

  ⟨E⟩ = [E₀ e^(–βE₀) + E₁ e^(–βE₁)]/[e^(–βE₀) + e^(–βE₁)]
      = E₀ + (E₁ – E₀)/(e^(β(E₁–E₀))+1).

(b) In the limits,
  T → 0   ⟹  ⟨E⟩ → E₀,
  T → ∞   ⟹  ⟨E⟩ → (E₀ + E₁)/2.

(c) The specific heat for N particles is given by

  C = N k (β (E₁ – E₀))² · e^(–β (E₁ – E₀)) / [1 + e^(–β (E₁ – E₀))]²,
   with β = 1/(kT).

(d) In the limits,
  T → 0   ⟹  C → 0,
  T → ∞   ⟹  C → 0.

────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & \langle E \rangle = \frac{E_0 e^{-\beta E_0}+E_1 e^{-\beta E_1}}{e^{-\beta E_0}+e^{-\beta E_1}} 
=\; E_0 + \frac{E_1-E_0}{e^{\beta(E_1-E_0)}+1},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & T\to 0: \langle E \rangle \to E_0,\quad T\to \infty: \langle E \rangle \to \frac{E_0+E_1}{2},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & C = N\,k\left[\beta(E_1-E_0)\right]^2\,\frac{e^{-\beta(E_1-E_0)}}{\left[1+ e^{-\beta(E_1-E_0)}\right]^2},\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad & T\to 0: C\to 0,\quad\quad\; T\to \infty: C\to 0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We begin by writing the Hamiltonian for a single particle that oscillates in one dimension. In general, the Hamiltonian is

  H = (p²/(2m)) + V(x).

The idea is to calculate the average energy per particle at temperature T and then differentiate with respect to T to get the heat capacity. In the high‐temperature (classical) limit, the partition function approach together with scaling laws can be used to deduce the answer without evaluating integrals explicitly.

Step 1. Kinetic Energy Contribution

For any system with quadratic momentum terms, the classical equipartition theorem tells us that each quadratic degree of freedom contributes an average energy of (1/2)k_B T. Since our Hamiltonian has the term p²/(2m), we have

  ⟨K.E.⟩ = (1/2)k_B T.

Step 2. Potential Energy Contribution by Scaling

Let the potential energy be of the form
  V(x) = C|x|^α,
where C is a constant and α determines the nature of the restoring force.

Using a scaling argument (or by a change of variable in the partition function) one finds that the x-integral contributes a factor proportional to T^(1/α). In particular, the logarithm of the x-part of the partition function varies as (1/α)lnT. Hence, differentiating with respect to T gives an average potential energy of
  ⟨V⟩ = (1/α) k_B T.
Thus, the total average energy per particle is
  ⟨E⟩ = (1/2 + 1/α) k_B T.
Differentiating with respect to T gives the heat capacity per particle:
  C_V = d⟨E⟩/dT = (1/2 + 1/α) k_B.

Now we apply this to our two cases.

Case (a): Restoring Force ∝ x

For a force proportional to x, the potential must be quadratic in x. That is, we write
  V(x)= (1/2) k x²,
which corresponds to α = 2 (with C = k/2).

Substituting α = 2 into our formula gives:
  ⟨E⟩ = (1/2 + 1/2) k_B T = k_B T,
and thus,
  C_V = k_B   (per particle).
For N particles, the total heat capacity is:
  C_V = N k_B.

Case (b): Restoring Force ∝ x³

A force proportional to x³ means that
  F(x) = -a x³   (with some constant a).
Since force is the negative derivative of the potential:
  F(x) = -dV/dx,
integrating gives:
  V(x) = (a/4)x⁴   (ignoring an integration constant).
This is of the form V(x) = Cx⁴ with α = 4 (and C = a/4).

Using our general result with α = 4:
  ⟨E⟩ = (1/2 + 1/4) k_B T = (3/4) k_B T,
and hence the heat capacity per particle is:
  C_V = (3/4) k_B.
For N particles, the total heat capacity is:
  C_V = N (3/4) k_B.

Final Answer:

 (a) For a restoring force proportional to x (harmonic oscillator), the heat capacity is 
  N k_B,
 (b) For a restoring force proportional to x³ (quartic potential), the heat capacity is 
  N (3/4) k_B.

Thus, the final answer is:
  \[\boxed{C_V = \begin{cases} N\,k_B, & \text{(force } \propto x\text{)}; \\ \frac{3}{4}\,N\,k_B, & \text{(force } \propto x^3\text{)}. \end{cases}}\]

We begin by considering the radiation inside the cavity as a “gas” of photons, each with energy ε and momentum k related by

  ε = c k       (1)

where c is the speed of light.

Step 1. Derivation of Pressure in Terms of Energy Density

Since the photons are moving in all directions, we must average their momentum transfer to the walls. For a single photon hitting a wall, the momentum change normal to the wall (if reflected elastically) is 2k cosθ, where θ is the angle between the photon's direction and the normal. To compute the pressure (force per unit area) exerted by many such photons, we must average over all directions.

The energy density u (energy per unit volume) of the radiation is given by

  u = (total energy in the cavity)/(volume).

A detailed kinetic theory calculation shows that the pressure p (momentum flux normal to a surface) is related to u by taking into account the angular distribution. In three dimensions the average of cos²θ over a hemisphere is 1/3, so one obtains

  p = (1/3) u       (2)

This is a standard result for a photon gas.

Step 2. Adiabatic Compression of Radiation

Now, consider radiation contained in a vessel with perfectly reflecting walls undergoing an adiabatic process (no heat exchange). For a reversible adiabatic process in thermodynamics, the entropy remains constant. For black-body radiation, the entropy S is related to the temperature T and volume V by

  S ∝ T³ V       (3)

Constant entropy (dS = 0) then implies that

  T³V = constant     (4)

or equivalently,

  T ∝ V^(–1/3).

The energy density u of the radiation is proportional to T⁴ (u = aT⁴, where a is the radiation constant). Therefore, we have

  u ∝ T⁴ ∝ V^(–4/3).    (5)

Since we already showed that the pressure is one-third the energy density, it follows that

  p = (1/3)u ∝ V^(–4/3).   (6)

Thus, multiplying both sides by V^(4/3) yields:

  p V^(4/3) = constant   (7)

This is the form

  PV^γ = constant 

with

  γ = 4/3.

Step 3. Final Answer

Thus, in summary, by treating the radiation as a photon gas we have shown that the pressure is one-third of the energy density, and for adiabatic compression of radiation the pressure and volume satisfy the equation

  PV^(4/3) = constant,

implying that the adiabatic index is

  γ = 4/3.

Final answer:

\[
\boxed{\gamma=\frac{4}{3}}
\]

We wish to calculate the contribution to the heat capacity coming from atoms that can occupy one of two energy levels. In (a) every atom has two levels at energies +Δ and –Δ (with Δ>0), while in (b) the splitting Δ of different atoms is not fixed but is uniformly distributed between 0 and Δ₀. (We ignore the usual Debye specific‐heat contribution.)

Let k denote Boltzmann’s constant and β = 1/(kT).

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): A Single Two–Level System with Splitting Δ
───────────────────────────── 
For an atom with two levels at energies E = +Δ and E = –Δ, the partition function is
  Z = exp(–βΔ) + exp(+βΔ) = 2 cosh(βΔ).

The average energy is
  U = [Δ exp(–βΔ) + (–Δ)exp(+βΔ)]/Z
    = –Δ [exp(βΔ) – exp(–βΔ)]/(2 cosh(βΔ))
    = –Δ tanh(βΔ).

To obtain the heat capacity, we differentiate with respect to T:
  C = dU/dT.

It is often easier to take the derivative using the chain rule. Writing U = –Δ tanh(x) with x =βΔ = Δ/(kT), we have

  dU/dT = –Δ · (d/dx tanh(x)) · (dx/dT)
      = –Δ · [sech²(x)] · (–Δ/(kT²))
      = Δ² sech²(x)/(kT²).

Thus the heat capacity per atom is
  C = k (Δ/(kT))² sech²(Δ/(kT)).

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): A Random Distribution of Splittings
───────────────────────────── 
Now suppose that in the glass the two–level systems have splittings Δ that are “random” in the sense that they are uniformly distributed between 0 and Δ₀. (We assume Δ₀ is some positive cutoff and we are interested in low–T where kT ≪ Δ₀.) In other words, the density of states for Δ is
  f(Δ) = 1/Δ₀, for 0 ≤ Δ ≤ Δ₀.

Thus the heat capacity per atom (averaged over the distribution) is
  C̄ = ∫₀^(Δ₀) dΔ f(Δ) C(Δ)
    = (1/Δ₀)∫₀^(Δ₀) dΔ k (Δ/(kT))² sech²(Δ/(kT)).

It is convenient to change the integration variable to
  u = Δ/(kT)  ⇒ dΔ = kT du.
Then the limits become u = 0 to u = Δ₀/(kT). In the low–temperature limit kT ≪ Δ₀ the upper limit is very large so that

  C̄ = (k/(Δ₀)) ∫₀^(Δ₀/(kT)) (kT du) (u² sech²(u))
    = (k²T/Δ₀) ∫₀^(∞) u² sech²(u) du.

Call
  I = ∫₀^(∞) u² sech²(u) du.
(I is a pure-number constant; its explicit evaluation is not needed since it does not depend on T, Δ, or Δ₀.)

Thus we have, at low temperatures, 
  C̄ ∝ (k²T/Δ₀).
That is, the average heat capacity of the two–level systems is linear in T.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers
───────────────────────────── 
(a) For a two–level system with energies ±Δ, the heat capacity per atom is

  C = k (Δ/(kT))² sech²(Δ/(kT)).

(b) For a distribution of two–level systems with Δ uniformly distributed between 0 and Δ₀, the low–temperature (kT ≪ Δ₀) heat capacity per atom is

  C̄ = (k²T/Δ₀) I,  with I = ∫₀^∞ u² sech²(u) du  a constant.

In summary, the heat capacity behaves as T² (in the scaling variable) for each two–level system, but after averaging over a flat distribution in Δ the overall low–temperature heat capacity becomes linear in T.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer in Latex Boxed Format
───────────────────────────── 

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & C = k \left(\frac{\Delta}{kT}\right)^2 \sech^2\left(\frac{\Delta}{kT}\right), \\
\text{(b)}\quad & \overline{C} = \frac{k^2 T}{\Delta_0} \int_0^\infty u^2 \sech^2(u)\,du \quad\text{(i.e. } \overline{C}\propto T\text{ at low }T\text{).}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We are given a situation where a window separates a room (with air at 25°C) from the outdoors (air at –15°C). Heat is transferred by convection at each face of the window according to

  Q_conv = 0.4×10⁻⁴ (Δt)^(5/4) [cal/(sec·cm²)],

with Δt the difference between the air and the contacting surface temperature. The window (thickness 2 mm, i.e. 0.2 cm) conducts heat at a rate governed by

  Q_cond = k (T_inside_surface – T_outside_surface) / L,

where k = 2×10⁻³ cal/(sec·cm·°C) and L = 0.2 cm (thus k/L = (2×10⁻³)/0.2 = 0.01 cal/(sec·cm²·°C)).

In the steady state the heat flux through the three “resistances” must be equal. Denote:
  T_i = the temperature at the inside surface of the window,
  T_o = the temperature at the outside surface of the window.

At the inside face (room side) the convective flux is
  Q_in = 0.4×10⁻⁴ (25 – T_i)^(5/4).

At the outside face (exterior side) the convective flux is
  Q_out = 0.4×10⁻⁴ (T_o – (–15))^(5/4) = 0.4×10⁻⁴ (T_o + 15)^(5/4).

Conduction through the window gives
  Q_cond = 0.01 (T_i – T_o).

Since the same heat Q must be passing through each “element” in series we have

(1) 0.4×10⁻⁴ (25 – T_i)^(5/4) = 0.01 (T_i – T_o),

(2) 0.01 (T_i – T_o) = 0.4×10⁻⁴ (T_o + 15)^(5/4).

Notice that the convective law is the same (with the temperature difference raised to the 5/4 power) on both sides. Thus, for consistency in the fluxes we must have

  25 – T_i = T_o + 15.

Let us define

  x ≡ 25 – T_i
  => T_i = 25 – x.
Also from the above equality, we have
  T_o = x – 15.

Then the conduction temperature drop is

  T_i – T_o = (25 – x) – (x – 15) = 25 – x – x + 15 = 40 – 2x.

Also, the convective flux (on either side) can be written in terms of x. In particular, from the inside face

  Q = 0.4×10⁻⁴ · x^(5/4).

And from conduction we have

  Q = 0.01 (40 – 2x).

Setting these equal, we obtain

  0.4×10⁻⁴ · x^(5/4) = 0.01 (40 – 2x).

Let’s simplify this equation. Notice that

  0.4×10⁻⁴ = 4×10⁻⁵.

So

  4×10⁻⁵ · x^(5/4) = 0.01 (40 – 2x).

It is easier to divide both sides by 0.01 (recall that 0.01 = 1×10⁻²):

  (4×10⁻⁵ / 1×10⁻²) · x^(5/4) = 40 – 2x.

Now, 4×10⁻⁵ / 1×10⁻² = 4×10⁻³ (since 10⁻⁵/10⁻² = 10⁻³). That gives

  4×10⁻³ · x^(5/4) = 40 – 2x.

It is convenient to divide by 2:

  2×10⁻³ · x^(5/4) = 20 – x    (★)

We now have the equation

  20 – x = 2×10⁻³ · x^(5/4).

Since convective resistances are quite high compared to the window’s conduction “resistance,” the temperatures on the two sides of the glass nearly “match” the convection drops. It turns out that x will be nearly the entire difference between 25° and the eventual surface temperatures. Let’s solve (★) for x approximately.

We need to solve:

  20 – x = 0.002 · x^(5/4).

Because the left side (20 – x) decreases as x increases, we look for a value x between 0 and 20. Testing a value:
• For x = 10:
  20 – 10 = 10,
  x^(5/4) = 10^(5/4) = exp((5/4) ln 10) ≈ exp(1.25×2.3026) ≈ exp(2.878) ≈ 17.8.
  Right side = 0.002×17.8 ≈ 0.0356,
  LHS massively larger than RHS.
• For x = 19:
  20 – 19 = 1,
  19^(5/4) = exp(1.25 ln 19) ≈ exp(1.25×2.944) ≈ exp(3.68) ≈ 39.7,
  Right side = 0.002×39.7 ≈ 0.0794,
  LHS = 1, so still LHS > RHS.
• As x → 20, LHS → 0. For instance, try x = 19.9:
  20 – 19.9 = 0.1,
  19.9^(5/4) ≈ exp(1.25 ln 19.9) with ln19.9 ≈ 2.993, product ≈ 3.741; exp(3.741) ≈ 42.0,
  RHS = 0.002×42.0 = 0.084,
  LHS = 0.1. They are nearly equal.
• Fine tuning: try x = 19.915:
  20 – 19.915 = 0.085,
  ln(19.915) ≈ 2.9935, so 19.915^(5/4) ≈ exp(1.25×2.9935) ≈ exp(3.7419) ≈ 42.17,
  RHS = 0.002×42.17 ≈ 0.08434,
  LHS = 0.085, which is very close.

Thus we take x ≈ 19.915. Recall that

  x = 25 – T_i  ⇒ T_i = 25 – x = 25 – 19.915 ≈ 5.085°C.

For completeness, note that the outside surface temperature is

  T_o = x – 15 ≈ 19.915 – 15 = 4.915°C.

Thus the temperature drop largely occurs across the convective boundaries. The conduction drop in the window is

  T_i – T_o ≈ 5.085 – 4.915 = 0.17°C,

which is very small compared to the convective drops of about 20°C on each side.

Final answer:

  The inner surface temperature of the window pane is approximately 5°C.

We wish to consider a “toy‐universe” that is a spherical cavity of radius R = 10^28 cm with “impenetrable” walls. We will treat the contents in two different cases.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): Blackbody Photons at T = 3 K
───────────────────────────── 

For a blackbody photon gas at temperature T the number density (number per unit volume) is given by

  n₍γ₎ = (16π ζ(3) / c³h³) (k_BT)³.

A useful “rule‐of‐thumb” is that for the cosmic microwave background at T ≃ 2.73 K one has about 410 photons/cm³. At T = 3 K the number density scales as T³ so that

  n₍γ₎ ≃ 410 × (3/2.73)³ ≃ 410 × (1.10)³ ≃ 410 × 1.33 ≃ 546 cm⁻³.

The volume of the spherical cavity is

  V = (4/3) π R³ = (4/3) π (10^28 cm)³ ≃ 4.19×10^84 cm³.

Thus the total number of photons is

  N₍γ₎ = n₍γ₎ V ≃ 546 cm⁻³ × 4.19×10^84 cm³ ≃ 2.3×10^87.

Next, the energy density of a blackbody radiation field is given by

  u = aT⁴,
  a = 7.5657×10⁻¹⁵ erg·cm⁻³·K⁻⁴.

For T = 3 K, we have

  u ≃ 7.5657×10⁻¹⁵ × (3⁴)
      = 7.5657×10⁻¹⁵ × 81 ≃ 6.13×10⁻¹³ erg/cm³.

The total energy is then

  U = uV ≃ 6.13×10⁻¹³ erg/cm³ × 4.19×10^84 cm³ ≃ 2.57×10^72 erg.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Fermi Gas of Electrons at T = 0 K
───────────────────────────── 

Now assume that at T = 0 K the cavity contains Nₑ = 10^80 electrons which fill a Fermi sea (i.e. have a Fermi–Dirac distribution at T = 0). The number density is

  nₑ = Nₑ/V = 10^80 / (4/3 π (10^28)³) ≃ 10^80 / (4.19×10^84) ≃ 2.38×10⁻⁵ electrons/cm³.

For a free Fermi gas the electrons fill all momentum states up to the Fermi momentum p_F. Converting to three dimensions the relation is

  nₑ = p_F³/(3π²ħ³).

Solving for p_F gives

  p_F = ħ (3π²nₑ)^(1/3).

We use:
  ħ ≃ 1.055×10⁻²⁷ erg·s   (in cgs, note 1 erg·s = 1 g·cm²/s),
  nₑ ≃ 2.38×10⁻⁵ cm⁻³.

Let’s first compute the factor inside the cube root:

  3π²nₑ = 3 × π² × 2.38×10⁻⁵.
Since π² ≃ 9.87, we have
  3π² ≃ 29.61,
so
  3π²nₑ ≃ 29.61 × 2.38×10⁻⁵ ≃ 7.05×10⁻⁴.

Taking the cube root:

  (7.05×10⁻⁴)^(1/3) ≃ 0.089    (since 0.089³ ≃ 7.05×10⁻⁴).

Thus,
  p_F ≃ 1.055×10⁻²⁷ erg·s × 0.089 ≃ 9.4×10⁻²⁹ g·cm/s.
(Recall that in cgs units momentum has the units g·cm/s.)

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers
───────────────────────────── 

(a) The total number of photons is approximately 2.3×10^87 and the total energy in these photons is about 2.6×10^72 erg.

(b) The Fermi momentum of the 10^80 electrons is approximately 9.4×10^(-29) g·cm/s.

Thus, our final answers are

  \[ \boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & N_{\gamma}\simeq 2.3\times 10^{87}\quad, \quad U\simeq 2.6\times10^{72}\,\text{erg},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & p_F\simeq 9.4\times10^{-29}\,\text{g}\cdot\text{cm/s}\,.
\end{aligned}
} \]

Step 1: Calculate the energy required to melt the ice at 0°C.  
The latent heat of fusion is given as 80 cal/g, so to melt 20 g of ice, the energy needed is:  

  Energy_melt = 20 g × 80 cal/g = 1600 cal.

Step 2: Once the ice melts, its water needs to be warmed from 0°C to the final temperature T (in °C). The energy required for this is:  

  Energy_warm = 20 g × 1 cal/(g·°C) × T = 20T cal.

Step 3: The hot water in the beaker (120 g at 70°C) will lose energy as it cools to the final temperature T. The energy lost by the water is:  

  Energy_loss = 120 g × 1 cal/(g·°C) × (70 - T) = 120(70 - T) cal.

Step 4: Set up the energy balance. The energy lost by the hot water is used to melt the ice and then warm the resulting water from 0°C to T:  

  120(70 - T) = 1600 + 20T.  

Step 5: Solve the equation:

  120 × 70 = 8400,  
  So, 8400 - 120T = 1600 + 20T.

Combine like terms:  

  8400 - 1600 = 120T + 20T  
  6800 = 140T

Thus, the final temperature is:  

  T = 6800 / 140 ≈ 48.57 °C.

We wish to find the equilibrium number density for photons in a black‐body radiation field at temperature T. Because photons are described by the Bose–Einstein distribution (with zero chemical potential), one may start with the formula for the number density of photons

  n = 2 ∫ (d³k/(2π)³) [1/(e^(ħω/(k_BT)) – 1)],

where the factor 2 accounts for the two independent polarization states of the photon, ω = c|k|, and the integration is over all momentum space.

Let’s work step by step.

───────────────────────────── Step 1. Change of Variables

Write the three–momentum integral in spherical coordinates:
  d³k = 4π k² dk.
Thus,
  n = 2 · (1/(2π)³) 4π ∫₀∞ k² dk/(e^(ħck/(k_BT)) – 1)
    = (1/π²)∫₀∞ k² dk/(e^(ħck/(k_BT)) – 1).

Now define a dimensionless integration variable x by
  x = (ħ c k)/(k_B T)   →  k = (k_B T/(ħ c)) x,
and note that
  dk = (k_B T/(ħ c)) dx.
The measure transforms as
  k² dk = (k_B T/(ħ c))³ x² dx.

───────────────────────────── Step 2. Write n in Terms of the Dimensionless Integral

Substitute into the expression for n:
  n = (1/π²) (k_B T/(ħ c))³ ∫₀∞ (x² dx)/(e^x – 1).

We may now define the dimensionless integral
  I = ∫₀∞ x²/(e^x – 1) dx.
It is known (by standard integration formulas involving the Riemann zeta function and the Gamma function) that:
  I = 2 ζ(3)   [since in general ∫₀∞ x^(n–1)/(e^x–1) dx = Γ(n) ζ(n) and here n = 3 with Γ(3) = 2! = 2].

Thus, our result can be written as
  n = (1/π²)(k_B T/(ħ c))³ I
or, explicitly,
  n = (2 ζ(3))/(π²) (k_B T/(ħ c))³.

This is our answer to part (a).

───────────────────────────── Step 3. Estimating the Number Density for T = 3 K

We now substitute nominal numerical values for the universal constants:
  k_B = 1.38 × 10^(–23) J/K,
  ħ   = 1.05 × 10^(–34) J·s,
  c   = 3.0 × 10^8 m/s,
  ζ(3) ≈ 1.202,
  π ≈ 3.14.

First, compute the dimensionless factor:
  (2 ζ(3))/(π²) = (2 × 1.202)/(3.14²) ≈ 2.404/9.87 ≈ 0.2437.

Next, calculate the combination (k_B T/(ħ c)) for T = 3 K:
  k_B T = 1.38 × 10^(–23) J/K × 3 K = 4.14 × 10^(–23) J,
  ħ c = 1.05 × 10^(–34) J·s × 3.0 × 10^8 m/s = 3.15 × 10^(–26) J·m.
Hence,
  k_B T/(ħ c) = (4.14 × 10^(–23))/(3.15 × 10^(–26)) ≈ 1314 m^(–1).

Now we take the cube:
  (k_B T/(ħ c))³ ≈ (1314)³.
Estimate (1314)³:
  1314² ≈ 1.73 × 10^6  (precisely, 1.73 × 10^6),
  Multiplying by 1314 gives ≈ 2.27 × 10^9 m^(–3).

Thus,
  n ≈ 0.2437 × 2.27 × 10^9 m^(–3) ≈ 5.53 × 10^8 m^(–3).

It is often stated that the cosmic microwave background radiation contains roughly hundreds of photons per cubic centimeter. Since 1 m³ = 10^6 cm³, our result
  n ≈ 5.53 × 10^8 m^(–3)
equates to about 550 photons/cm³, which is consistent with established estimates.

───────────────────────────── Final Answer

(a) The photon number density in terms of T and the universal constants is

  n = (1/π²)(k_B T/(ħ c))³ ∫₀∞ x²/(e^x –1) dx ≡ (2 ζ(3))/(π²)(k_B T/(ħ c))³.

(b) For T = 3 K, this gives an estimated photon density of approximately

  n ≈ 5.5 × 10^8 m^(–3).

\[
\boxed{n = \frac{2\zeta(3)}{\pi^2}\left(\frac{k_BT}{\hbar c}\right)^3 \quad\text{and}\quad n \approx 5.5\times10^8\,\text{m}^{-3}\text{ for }T=3\,\text{K}.}
\]

We wish to calculate the heat capacity (specific heat) for a one‐dimensional lattice of N oscillators with “spring‐constant” mω², where the dispersion relation for the normal modes is

  ωₖ = ω √[2(1 − cos(ka))],

with k = 2πn/(aN) and n an integer running essentially from –N/2 to +N/2. In the Debye approximation one “linearizes” the spectrum for small k and replaces the true density of modes by that appropriate to a linear dispersion. (Later we will show that the low–T behavior is determined by the linear part of the dispersion while the high temperature limit recovers classical equipartition.)

Below is a step‐by‐step derivation.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Linearizing the Dispersion (Debye Approximation)

For small k we have
  cos(ka) ≈ 1 - ½ (ka)².
Thus,
  ωₖ ≈ ω √[2(1 - (1 - ½ (ka)²)] = ω √[ (ka)²] = ωa |k|.
We define the speed of sound as
  c = ωa.
Then the dispersion is simply
  ω = c|k|.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Determining the Debye Cutoff Frequency

The one–dimensional system has total length L = Na. In a 1d system with linear dispersion the density of states is constant:
  g(ω) = (L/π)(dk/dω) = L/(πc) = (Na)/(πc).
We now choose the cutoff frequency ω_D so that the total number of modes equals N:
  ∫₀^(ω_D)g(ω)dω = N ⟹ (Na/(πc)) ω_D = N ⟹ ω_D = (πc)/a = πω.
Thus, the Debye cutoff frequency is
  ω_D = πω.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Expression for the Internal Energy

For a quantum harmonic oscillator of frequency ω the thermal energy (dropping the T‐independent zero–point energy) is
  ⟨E(ω)⟩ = ħω/(e^(ħω/(k_BT)) − 1).
Thus the total energy of the lattice is
  U = ∑ₖ ⟨E(ωₖ)⟩ → ∫₀^(ω_D)dω  g(ω) [ħω/(e^(ħω/(k_BT)) − 1)].

Since g(ω) = (Na)/(πc) and c = ωa, we note that
  g(ω) = N/(πω)
(with the proper change of variables so that the total number of modes is N). Hence,
  U = N/(πω) ∫₀^(ω_D)dω [ħω/(e^(ħω/(k_BT)) − 1)].
Let’s now change variables by defining
  x = ħω/(k_BT) ⟹ ω = (k_BT/ħ)x and dω = (k_BT/ħ)dx.
The upper limit becomes
  x_D = ħω_D/(k_BT) = (ħπω)/(k_BT).
It is convenient to define the “Debye temperature” θ_D by
  θ_D = ħπω/k_B    (so that x_D = θ_D/T).

Replacing everything, we obtain
  U = N/(πω) × ∫₀^(θ_D/T) (k_BT/ħ) dx · ħ (k_BT/ħ)x/(e^x−1)
    = N k_B²T²/(πωħ) ∫₀^(θ_D/T) x/(e^x−1) dx.

Now note that since θ_D = ħπω/k_B, we have
  πωħ = k_Bθ_D.
Thus, we may write the internal energy as
  U = N k_B T²/θ_D ∫₀^(θ_D/T) [x/(e^(x) − 1)] dx.
It is now a simple matter to take the derivative with respect to T to obtain the heat capacity.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Calculating the Heat Capacity

The specific heat is
  C = dU/dT.
It is convenient to define
  I(ξ) = ∫₀^(ξ) [x/(e^(x)−1)] dx  with ξ = θ_D/T.
Then
  U = N k_B T²/θ_D · I(ξ).

Taking the derivative with respect to T we must remember that ξ = θ_D/T so that dξ/dT = –θ_D/T². Thus,
  C = dU/dT = N k_B { (2T/θ_D) I(ξ) + [T²/θ_D] · (dI/dξ)(dξ/dT) } 
      = N k_B { (2T/θ_D) I(ξ) − [T²/θ_D] (θ_D/T²) · (ξ/(e^(ξ) − 1)) }
      = N k_B { (2T/θ_D) I(ξ) − [ξ/(e^(ξ) − 1)] }.
This is our general expression for the specific heat.

──────────────────────────────
Step 5. High–Temperature (T → ∞) Limit

When T ≫ θ_D (i.e. T → ∞) we have ξ = θ_D/T ≪ 1. In this limit we can expand the integrand in I(ξ):

For small x, 
  x/(e^x − 1) ≈ 1 − x/2 + x²/12 − … 
so that
  I(ξ) = ∫₀^(ξ) (1 − x/2 + x²/12 − …) dx 
    ≈ ξ − ξ²/4 + ξ³/36 − … .

Also, expanding the second term,
  ξ/(e^(ξ) − 1) ≈ 1 − ξ/2 + ξ²/12 − … .

Now substitute into the expression for C:
  C = N k_B { (2T/θ_D)[ξ − ξ²/4 + ξ³/36] − [1 − ξ/2 + ξ²/12] }.
But note that (2T/θ_D)ξ = 2T/θ_D · (θ_D/T) = 2. Also, writing the next terms (and recalling that ξ = θ_D/T) we get:
  (2T/θ_D)(ξ²/4) = (θ_D)/(2T),  (2T/θ_D)(ξ³/36) = (θ_D²)/(18T²).

Thus,
  C = N k_B { 2 − (θ_D/(2T)) + (θ_D²/(18T²)) − [1 − (θ_D/(2T)) + (θ_D²/(12T²))] }.
Combine the terms:
  2 − 1 = 1,
and notice that the first–order terms in θ_D/T cancel; the quadratic terms combine to give:
  (θ_D²/(18T²) − θ_D²/(12T²)) = −(θ_D²/(36T²)).
Thus, for high T we have
  C ≈ N k_B [ 1 − (1/36)(θ_D/T)² + … ].
Recalling that θ_D = πħω/k_B we may also write this as
  C ≈ N k_B [ 1 − (π²/36)(ħω/(k_BT))² + … ].
In the classical limit T → ∞ the heat capacity per oscillator tends to k_B (Dulong–Petit law in 1d).

──────────────────────────────
Step 6. Low–Temperature (T → 0) Limit

For T ≪ θ_D, i.e. ξ = θ_D/T ≫ 1. In this case the upper limit in I(ξ) can be replaced by infinity:
  I(∞) = ∫₀^∞ x/(e^x−1) dx.
This is a standard integral which evaluates to
  I(∞) = π²/6.
Also, for ξ → ∞ the term
  ξ/(e^(ξ) − 1) → 0.
Thus, from the expression for C we find
  C = N k_B (2T/θ_D)(π²/6) = N k_B (π² T/(3θ_D)).
Since θ_D = πħω/k_B we obtain
  C = N (π² T k_B)/(3(πħω/k_B)) = N (π k_B²)/(3ħω) T.
Thus, in the low–temperature limit the specific heat is linear in T.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

We have found that the specific heat (per N particles) in the Debye approximation is given by

  For T → ∞:
   C ≈ N k_B [ 1 − (π²/36)(ħω/(k_BT))² + … ],

  For T → 0:
   C ≈ N (π k_B²/(3ħω)) T.

These results show that the 1d Debye solid recovers the classical value N k_B at high T with quantum corrections of order (ħω/(k_BT))² and that at low T the specific heat vanishes linearly in T.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
C(T\to\infty) &\approx N k_B \left[1 - \frac{\pi^2}{36}\left(\frac{\hbar\omega}{k_BT}\right)^2 + \cdots\right],\\[1mm]
C(T\to 0) &\approx \frac{N\pi k_B^2}{3\hbar\omega}\,T.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to compute the rotational contributions to the molar specific heat (at constant volume) and to the absolute entropy for a dilute gas of diatomic molecules each having two atoms that are different. (Because the two atoms are different there is no symmetry‐factor in the partition sum.) In our model the only “active” rotational degree of freedom is that corresponding to rotations about an axis perpendicular to the bond (actually there are two such directions; however, when one “derives” the familiar rigid‐rotor energy spectrum it turns out that the energy eigenvalues are given by

  E_J = (ħ²/[2I]) J(J + 1),  J = 0, 1, 2, . . .

for a linear molecule having two rotational degrees of freedom – and that is the spectrum we shall use).

It is convenient to define the “rotational temperature”
  θ₍rot₎ = ħ²/(2I k),
so that the energy levels are written
  E_J = kθ₍rot₎ J(J+1).
Note that the characteristic energy gap from the ground state (J = 0) to the first excited state (J = 1) is
  ΔE = E₁ – E₀ = 2kθ₍rot₎ = ħ²/I.
Thus the two limiting cases we are to consider may be expressed as
  (a) kT ≫ ħ²/I  (i.e. T ≫ (ħ²/I)/k)  (high‐temperature limit)
  (b) kT ≪ ħ²/I  (i.e. T ≪ (ħ²/I)/k)  (low‐temperature limit).

It is sometimes more convenient to work in “dimensionless” variables. For example, we may define

  x ≡ ħ²/(I kT)    (so that x ≪ 1 in the high–T limit and x ≫ 1 in the low–T limit).

We now proceed with the two cases.

───────────────────────────── 
Case (a): kT ≫ ħ²/I  (or, equivalently, x ≪ 1)
─────────────────────────────

At high temperature many rotational levels are excited so that the sum
  Z₍rot₎ = ∑₍J=0₎∞ (2J + 1) exp[–β E_J] = ∑₍J=0₎∞ (2J + 1) exp[–θ₍rot₎ J(J+1)/T]
can be replaced by its classical (high–T) approximation. (Also note that for a heteronuclear molecule the “symmetry factor” is 1.) A standard result is that in the high–T limit one obtains
  Z₍rot₎ ≈ T/θ₍rot₎ = 2I kT/ħ².
Because the rotational energy is quadratic (when treated classically) in the two “angular coordinates” (or, equivalently, there are 2 quadratic degrees of freedom) the equipartition theorem tells us that the mean rotational energy per molecule is

  ⟨E₍rot₎⟩ = kT     (i.e. (1/2)kT for each degree of freedom).

Thus the molar rotational internal energy is
  U₍rot₎ = Nₐ kT = RT,
and therefore the molar rotational specific heat (at constant volume) is

  C₍V,rot₎ ≡ (∂U/∂T)₍V₎ = R.

Next, the rotational contribution to the molar Helmholtz free energy is
  A₍rot₎ = –RT ln Z₍rot₎ = –RT [ ln(2I kT/ħ²) ],
and hence the absolute molar entropy from the rotations is obtained by
  S₍rot₎ = –(∂A/∂T)₍V₎
so that
  S₍rot₎ = R ln(2I kT/ħ²) + R.
Thus, to lowest order in the high–T regime we have:

  C₍V,rot₎ = R            (1)
  S₍rot₎ = R[ ln(2I kT/ħ²) + 1 ].  (2)

───────────────────────────── 
Case (b): kT ≪ ħ²/I  (or, equivalently, x ≫ 1)
─────────────────────────────

At very low T the gap between the ground state and excited rotational levels is very large compared with kT. In this limit only the lowest levels are populated. Since the energy levels are

  E_J = (ħ²/[2I]) J(J+1),
the lowest levels are:
  J = 0, with energy 0 (non–degenerate),
  J = 1, with energy E₁ = ħ²/I (degeneracy g₁ = 3),
and higher levels are even more strongly suppressed by the Boltzmann factor exp(–E_J/(kT)). Thus, to lowest order the rotational partition function is

  Z₍rot₎ ≈ 1 + 3 exp(–ħ²/(I kT)).
It is now straightforward to compute the internal energy. We have

  U₍rot₎ = (1/Z) ∑ J g_J E_J exp(–βE_J)
≈ [ 3 (ħ²/I) exp(–ħ²/(I kT)) ] / [ 1 + 3 exp(–ħ²/(I kT)) ].
Since exp(–ħ²/(I kT)) ≪ 1 (because ħ²/(I kT) ≫ 1) we may approximate
  U₍rot₎ ≈ 3 (ħ²/I) exp(–ħ²/(I kT)).
Now, differentiating with respect to T gives the contribution to the specific heat. It is often easier to do the differentiation by writing
  U₍rot₎ ≈ 3 (ħ²/I) exp(–x)   with  x = ħ²/(I kT).
Noting that
  d(exp(–x))/dT = exp(–x) · (dx/dT)   and  dx/dT = –(ħ²/(I k))(1/T²),
we get
  dU/dT ≈ 3 (ħ²/I) exp(–x)·(ħ²/(I kT²))
or
  C₍V,rot₎ ≡ dU/dT ≈ 3·(ħ²/I)²·[1/(kT²)] exp(–ħ²/(I kT)).
Thus, to lowest order in the low–T limit we have

  C₍V,rot₎ ≈ 3R (ħ²/(I kT))² exp(–ħ²/(I kT)),   (3)
where we have written the result per mole (i.e. k is replaced by R when multiplied by Avogadro’s number).

Next, we compute the entropy from the partition function. In general,
  S = R ( ln Z + T (∂ ln Z/∂T) ).
Here
  Z₍rot₎ ≈ 1 + 3 exp(–ħ²/(I kT)),
so for small ε ≡ 3 exp(–ħ²/(I kT)) (with ε ≪ 1)
  ln Z₍rot₎ ≈ 3 exp(–ħ²/(I kT)).
Also, differentiating ln Z with respect to T gives a term proportional to (ħ²/(I kT²)) exp(–ħ²/(I kT)). Keeping the lowest order term we find
  S₍rot₎ ≈ 3R exp(–ħ²/(I kT))
       + R·3 (ħ²/(I kT)) exp(–ħ²/(I kT))
= 3R (1 + ħ²/(I kT)) exp(–ħ²/(I kT)).   (4)

Thus, in the low–T limit the rotational contribution to the entropy is exponentially small.

───────────────────────────── 
Summary of Answers
─────────────────────────────

In what follows our final answers (with “lowest order nonzero” contributions) are given in the two regimes:

(a) High temperature (kT ≫ ħ²/I):
  Rotational specific heat:  C₍V,rot₎ = R.
  Rotational entropy:     S₍rot₎ = R [ ln(2I kT/ħ²) + 1 ].

(b) Low temperature (kT ≪ ħ²/I):
  Rotational specific heat:  C₍V,rot₎ ≈ 3R (ħ²/(I kT))² exp(–ħ²/(I kT)).
  Rotational entropy:     S₍rot₎ ≈ 3R (1 + ħ²/(I kT)) exp(–ħ²/(I kT)).

─────────────────────────────

─────────────────────────────

The key is to ask: “What order‐of‐magnitude for the thermal conductivity is needed to smooth out the daily temperature oscillations over only 10 cm?” Typical measurements for granite yield a conductivity of only a few ×10⁻³ cal/(s·cm·°C).

Step 1. Recall that the conduction length scale L for a periodic (diurnal) temperature variation is roughly given by

  L ≈ √(ατ)

where α is the thermal diffusivity and τ is the period (≈ 86400 s). For granite, the diffusivity is low enough that the daily temperature wave is substantially attenuated within about 10 cm. Somehow this “damping” is suggestive of a relatively low conduction; if the conductivity were high (say, orders of magnitude larger), the damping would occur over a much larger distance.

Step 2. Thermal diffusivity α is given by

  α = k/(ρc)

where k is the thermal conductivity, ρ is the density, and c is the specific heat. For typical rocks like granite, ρc is such that k on the order of a few ×10⁻³ cal/(s·cm·°C) is consistent with the 10 cm damping depth.

Step 3. Among the choices (5×10⁻³, 5×10⁻¹, 5×10², or 5×10⁵ cal/(s·cm·°C)), notice that 5×10⁻³ is the only one that is low enough to provide the observed damping behavior.

Thus, the thermal conductivity of granite is approximately

  5×10⁻³ cal/(s·cm·°C).

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{5 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{cal/(s·cm·°C)}}
\]

We wish to show several important facts about a radiation “gas”. In what follows we treat radiation in equilibrium (blackbody radiation) and use kinetic theory and thermodynamic considerations.

────────────────────────
Step (a): Radiation Pressure on a Perfectly Reflecting Wall

Imagine a cavity filled with an isotropic radiation field with energy density u. Consider a small element of area on the wall and let photons impinge on this wall. A photon of momentum p (with p = E/c) striking the wall will reflect elastically; hence, the normal component of its momentum will reverse and the momentum change is Δp = 2p cosθ (where θ is the angle between the direction of the photon and the normal to the wall).

Because the radiation is isotropic, we have to average over all directions. The pressure is the momentum flux normal to the wall per unit time. A detailed kinetic theory calculation shows that this average introduces a factor of 1/3 when integrating cos²θ over an isotropic angular distribution. (One way to see this is to note that for an isotropic distribution in three dimensions, the average value of the square of the cosine of the angle with any fixed direction is 1/3.) Thus, one shows that

  Pressure p = (1/3) u.

────────────────────────
Step (b): Thermodynamic Nature of Blackbody Radiation

For a cavity in thermal equilibrium (blackbody radiation), the radiation comes into equilibrium with the walls which are at a fixed temperature T. In strict equilibrium the radiation field totally fills the cavity and its macroscopic properties (such as its energy density u) are determined solely by T. In other words, once thermal equilibrium is established, u can depend only on the temperature T and not on the geometrical dimensions of the cavity or on the specific material properties of the walls.

A short argument is as follows. Suppose we define the total internal energy as U(T,V). For radiation the energy density u = U/V is a function only of T (as one may demonstrate using detailed mode counting in a cavity – the famous result being u = aT⁴ where a is a constant). Thus, neither the volume V nor the nature of the walls enters into the value of u. Therefore, we conclude that the energy density of blackbody radiation is independent of the size of the cavity and the material making up the walls.

────────────────────────
Step (c): Deriving p(T) from Thermodynamic Reasoning

We are now told that:
 (1) p = p(T) (i.e. the pressure depends only on temperature), and
 (2) The internal energy is given by U = 3p(T)V (since u = U/V = 3p(T) by (a)).

We now use thermodynamics. Begin with the first law written for a reversible change:
  dU = T dS – p dV.
Since U is a function of T and V and we already have U(T,V) = 3p(T)V, let us differentiate U with respect to V at constant T:
  (∂U/∂V)_T = 3 p(T).
On the other hand, from a standard thermodynamic relation (which comes from demanding that dU must be an exact differential) we have
  (∂U/∂V)_T = T (∂p/∂T)_V – p.
But p depends only on T so the derivative is taken at constant T. Equate the two expressions for (∂U/∂V)_T:
  3 p(T) = T (dp/dT) – p(T).
Rearrange this equation:
  T (dp/dT) = 4 p(T).
This is a simple first–order differential equation. Separating variables gives
  (dp/p) = 4 (dT/T).
Integrate:
  ∫ (1/p) dp = 4 ∫ (1/T) dT  ⟹  ln p = 4 ln T + constant.
Exponentiating, we have:
  p(T) ∝ T⁴.
Thus, up to an unspecified multiplicative constant, the pressure is proportional to T⁴. Once the proportionality constant is fixed by experimental or microscopic theory (it turns out that p = (1/3)aT⁴ for blackbody radiation, where a is the radiation constant), the functional form is completely determined.

────────────────────────
Final Answer

The pressure exerted by an isotropic radiation field of energy density u on a perfectly reflecting wall is p = u/3. For blackbody radiation in a cavity the energy density is uniquely determined by the temperature, independent of the cavity’s size or wall material. Finally, using the thermodynamic relation U = 3pV and the first law we derive that

  T (dp/dT) = 4 p(T),

so that

  p(T) ∝ T⁴.

Thus, our final result is

  p(T) = constant · T⁴.

────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Box

\[
\boxed{p = \frac{u}{3},\quad u = u(T),\quad \text{and} \quad p(T) \propto T^4.}
\]

We start with the energy levels
  E₁ = 0,  E₂ = ε,  E₃ = 10ε.
A molecule at temperature T is described (in the canonical ensemble) by the partition function

  Z = exp(–E₁/(kT)) + exp(–E₂/(kT)) + exp(–E₃/(kT))
    = 1 + exp(–ε/(kT)) + exp(–10ε/(kT)).

Step 1. Showing that “at sufficiently low temperatures only E₁ and E₂ are populated”

Notice that the relative population of level i is proportional to exp(–Eᵢ/(kT)). For the third level we have the Boltzmann factor 
  exp(–10ε/(kT)).
Thus if

  10ε/(kT) ≫ 1    or   kT ≪ 10ε,
then exp(–10ε/(kT)) is exponentially small compared with unity or even exp(–ε/(kT)) (unless T is extremely low) and therefore the third level is essentially unpopulated. In words, as long as the temperature is much less than 10ε/k, only levels E₁ and E₂ play a role.

Step 2. Average Energy of the Molecule

The general expression for the thermal average energy is

  ⟨E⟩ = (1/Z) Σᵢ Eᵢ exp(–Eᵢ/(kT)).

Thus with all three levels

  ⟨E⟩ = [0 · 1 + ε · exp(–ε/(kT)) + 10ε · exp(–10ε/(kT))] / [1 + exp(–ε/(kT)) + exp(–10ε/(kT))].

When kT ≪ 10ε the term exp(–10ε/(kT)) is negligible so that

  Z ≃ 1 + exp(–ε/(kT))
  and
  ⟨E⟩ ≃ ε exp(–ε/(kT)) / [1 + exp(–ε/(kT))].
This is the familiar result for a two‐level system.

Step 3. Specific Heat Cᵥ

The specific heat (per molecule) is given by the temperature derivative of the average energy,
  Cᵥ = d⟨E⟩/dT.
For the two‐level case, it is usually more convenient to express the answer in “Schottky anomaly” form. We introduce the variable

  x = ε/(kT)
so that exp(–ε/(kT)) = exp(–x). Then we have

  ⟨E⟩ = ε exp(–x)/[1 + exp(–x)].

It is a standard result that for a two–level system the heat capacity is

  Cᵥ = (ε²/(kT²)) · [exp(–ε/(kT))/(1+exp(–ε/(kT)))²].
To be completely explicit,
  Cᵥ = ε²/(kT²) · [exp(–x)/(1+exp(–x))²].

Since we usually give the specific heat per mole we multiply by Avogadro’s number Nₐ. Noting that R = kNₐ we write

  Cᵥ(mole) = R (ε/(kT))² · [exp(–ε/(kT))/(1+exp(–ε/(kT)))²] .

Step 4. Sketching Cᵥ as a Function of T

For a two–level system the specific heat as a function of temperature has the familiar “Schottky anomaly”: 
 • At very low T (kT ≪ ε), exp(–ε/(kT)) ≪ 1 so that Cᵥ is extremely small.
 • As T increases (with kT on the order of ε) Cᵥ increases and reaches a maximum.
 • For still higher T (kT ≫ ε), the populations of the two levels tend to equalize so that ⟨E⟩ tends to a constant (≈ε/2) and, hence, Cᵥ decreases to zero.
Thus Cᵥ rises from zero at T = 0, reaches a peak at a temperature of order T ≃ ε/k (more precisely, one finds the maximum near x = ε/(kT) ≃ 1–3, the exact maximum being determined by the condition dCᵥ/dT = 0), and then falls off for T ≫ ε/k.

To summarize, we have shown that:
 • Only levels E₁ and E₂ are appreciably populated if kT ≪ 10ε.
 • The average energy is
  ⟨E⟩ = [ε exp(–ε/(kT)) + 10ε exp(–10ε/(kT))] / [1 + exp(–ε/(kT)) + exp(–10ε/(kT))],
which for kT ≪ 10ε reduces to
  ⟨E⟩ ≈ ε exp(–ε/(kT)) / [1 + exp(–ε/(kT))].
 • The molar specific heat is
  Cᵥ = R (ε/(kT))² · [exp(–ε/(kT))/(1+exp(–ε/(kT)))²],
which exhibits a Schottky anomaly, peaking when kT is of order ε.

Thus, our final answers are:

 – Sufficiently low temperatures means kT ≪ 10ε.
 – The average energy is  ⟨E⟩ = [ε e^(–ε/(kT)) + 10ε e^(–10ε/(kT))] ⁄ [1 + e^(–ε/(kT)) + e^(–10ε/(kT))]   (≈ ε e^(–ε/(kT))/(1+e^(–ε/(kT))) for kT ≪ 10ε).
 – The molar specific heat is  Cᵥ = R (ε/(kT))² · [e^(–ε/(kT))/(1+e^(–ε/(kT)))²].

Finally, we box the answer in LaTeX:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{Condition:}&\quad kT\ll 10\,\varepsilon.\\[1mm]
Z &= 1+e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}+e^{-10\varepsilon/(kT)}\approx1+e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}\\[1mm]
\langle E\rangle &= \frac{\varepsilon\,e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}+10\varepsilon\,e^{-10\varepsilon/(kT)}}{1+e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}+e^{-10\varepsilon/(kT)}}
\approx \frac{\varepsilon\,e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}}{1+e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}}\\[2mm]
C_v &= \frac{d\langle E\rangle}{dT}
=\frac{\varepsilon^2}{kT^2}\frac{e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}}{\Bigl(1+e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}\Bigr)^2}\\[2mm]
\text{(Molar }C_v\text{)}&\quad C_v = R\left(\frac{\varepsilon}{kT}\right)^2\frac{e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}}{\Bigl(1+e^{-\varepsilon/(kT)}\Bigr)^2}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]
Any answer equivalent to the above is correct.

We are given that the energy for one particle is

  E(z) = a z²,

and that z can run from –∞ to +∞. The particles obey Boltzmann statistics so that the probability density is proportional to exp(–βE) where β = 1/(kT).

---------------

Step (a): Calculate the average energy per particle

The average energy ⟨E⟩ is given by

  ⟨E⟩ = (∫₋∞^∞ E(z) e^(–βE(z)) dz) / (∫₋∞^∞ e^(–βE(z)) dz).

Substitute E(z) = a z²:

  ⟨E⟩ = (∫₋∞^∞ a z² e^(–βa z²) dz) / (∫₋∞^∞ e^(–βa z²) dz).

Recall the standard Gaussian integrals:
  ∫₋∞^∞ e^(–γ z²) dz = √(π/γ),
  ∫₋∞^∞ z² e^(–γ z²) dz = ½ √(π)/γ^(3/2).

In our case, let γ = βa.

Compute the denominator:
  Z = ∫₋∞^∞ e^(–βa z²) dz = √(π/(βa)).

Compute the numerator:
  N = a ∫₋∞^∞ z² e^(–βa z²) dz = a · [½ √(π)/(βa)^(3/2)]
     = ½ √(π) · a / ( (βa)^(3/2) )
     = ½ √(π) / (β^(3/2)a^(1/2)).

Thus, the average energy is
  ⟨E⟩ = {½ √(π)/(β^(3/2)a^(1/2))} / {√(π/(βa))}
     = {½/(β^(3/2)a^(1/2))} / {1/(√(βa))}
     = ½ · (√(βa))/(β^(3/2)a^(1/2))
     = ½ · 1/β
     = 1/(2β).

Since β = 1/(kT), we have

  ⟨E⟩ = kT/2.

---------------

Step (b): Principle of Equipartition of Energy

The principle of equipartition of energy states that in thermal equilibrium, each independent quadratic degree of freedom in the classical Hamiltonian contributes an average energy of kT/2. In the calculation above, the energy E = a z² is a quadratic form in z. Thus, our result of ⟨E⟩ = kT/2 is a direct manifestation of the equipartition theorem.

Equipartition theorem is foundational in classical statistical mechanics because it tells us that every quadratic term (e.g., kinetic energy terms like p²/(2m) or potential energy terms like kx²/2) contributes equally to the thermal energy of the system. This principle not only validates the step-by-step calculation but also helps predict and understand energy distribution in systems with many degrees of freedom.

---------------

Final Answer

\[
\boxed{\langle E \rangle = \frac{kT}{2} \quad \text{and each quadratic degree of freedom contributes} \; \frac{kT}{2} \; \text{to the average energy (equipartition theorem)}.}
\]

We wish to show two things. First, that if the gas obeys
  γ = Cₚ/Cᵥ = 5/3,
then the “microscopic” kinetic energy (i.e. the random thermal motions of the gas particles) is equal to the total internal energy. Second, that a self‐gravitating (finite) gaseous configuration (in Newtonian gravity) can be in equilibrium only if
  γ > 4/3.

In what follows we describe a step‐by‐step derivation.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. The Virial Theorem for a Gaseous Configuration

For a fluid in motion under its own gravity the scalar virial theorem may be derived by multiplying the Euler equation by the “position vector” r and integrating over the whole volume. One finds (after some integration by parts and under the assumption that the pressure vanishes on the surface of the configuration) that

  2K + 3∫p dV + Ω = 0    (1)

Here

• K is the “macroscopic” kinetic energy associated with the bulk motion. (In a static configuration in hydrostatic equilibrium the bulk kinetic energy is zero; however, when one considers the energy budget of the gas the microscopic thermal motions provide the internal energy.)

• p is the local pressure;

• Ω is the gravitational potential energy (which for self‐gravitating systems is negative).

For a fluid in strict hydrostatic equilibrium we have no bulk motion so that K = 0 and (1) becomes

  3∫p dV + Ω = 0    (2)

───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. Relating the Pressure Integral to the Internal Energy

For an ideal gas the internal energy density (per unit volume) is given by

  u = p/(γ – 1).

Thus, the total internal energy is

  U_int = ∫ u dV = 1/(γ – 1) ∫ p dV.
  ⇒ ∫ p dV = (γ – 1) U_int.    (3)

Substitute (3) into (2) to obtain

  Ω = –3(γ – 1) U_int.    (4)

It is also known from the standard form of the virial theorem for self‐gravitating systems that (when the whole system is in motion)

  Ω = –2K.    (5)

This relation “splits” the gravitational binding energy equally between kinetic energy and the pressure (internal energy) when the system is virialized.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 3. Deriving (a): Kinetic Energy vs. Internal Energy for γ = 5/3

Combining (4) and (5) we write

  –2K = –3(γ – 1) U_int   ⇒  2K = 3(γ – 1) U_int.
  Thus, K = (3/2)(γ – 1) U_int.    (6)

Now, if we require that the (microscopic) kinetic energy be equal to the total internal energy, that is
  K = U_int,
then (6) becomes

  (3/2)(γ – 1) U_int = U_int.
  Cancel U_int (which is nonzero) to get
  (3/2)(γ – 1) = 1  ⇒  γ – 1 = 2/3  ⇒  γ = 5/3.

This is the desired result for part (a).

───────────────────────────── 
Step 4. Deriving (b): Equilibrium Requires γ > 4/3

For a self‐gravitating gaseous sphere the total energy is given by the sum of its internal energy and gravitational potential energy:

  E = U_int + Ω.

Using (4) we have

  E = U_int – 3(γ – 1) U_int = [1 – 3(γ – 1)] U_int
     = (4 – 3γ) U_int.    (7)

For the configuration to be gravitationally bound (stable) we must have E < 0. Since U_int is positive we require

  4 – 3γ < 0  ⇒  γ > 4/3.

Thus, Newtonian gravitational equilibrium is possible only for γ > 4/3.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) The relation

  K = (3/2)(γ – 1) U_int
shows that K = U_int if (3/2)(γ – 1) = 1, i.e. if γ = 5/3.

(b) In order that the total energy E = (4 – 3γ)U_int be negative (bound system), one must have γ > 4/3.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer in LaTeX Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & K = \frac{3}{2}(\gamma-1)U_{\rm int} \quad\Rightarrow\quad K=U_{\rm int}\;\text{when}\; \gamma=\frac{5}{3}, \\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & E = (4-3\gamma)U_{\rm int}<0 \quad\Rightarrow\quad \gamma>\frac{4}{3}\,. 
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We must set up the energy balance. As the ice grows by a thickness dx in time dt (at a given moment when the ice is x cm thick), the latent heat released in freezing an incremental layer must be conducted through the ice.

Step 1. Energy flux by conduction

The top of the ice is at –20°C, while the ice–water interface is at 0°C. Thus, the temperature drop across the ice is ΔT = 20°C. With thermal conductivity κ, the conductive energy flux (energy per unit area per unit time) is given by

  Q = κ (ΔT/x).

Here the heat flows upward through the ice that acts like a slab of thickness x.

Step 2. Energy needed to freeze a small layer

When a layer of thickness dx freezes, the mass per unit area is ρ dx (with ρ = 1 g/cm³) and the latent heat released per gram is L. Thus the energy released per unit area is

  dE = L ρ dx.

For the freezing to occur, the rate at which energy is released must equal the rate at which energy is conducted away. That gives

  L ρ (dx/dt) = κ (ΔT/x).

Step 3. (a) Rate of Increase When x = 1 cm

Solve for dx/dt:

  dx/dt = κ (ΔT)/(L ρ x).

Substitute in the numbers (with κ = 5×10⁻³ cal/(cm·sec·°C), ΔT = 20°C, L = 80 cal/g, ρ = 1 g/cm³, and x = 1 cm):

  dx/dt = (5×10⁻³ × 20)/(80×1×1)
     = (0.1)/(80)
     = 0.00125 cm/sec.

Thus, when the ice is 1 cm thick it is growing at a rate of 0.00125 cm/sec.

Step 4. (b) Time for the thickness to double

Now note that the growth rate depends on x. We have the differential equation

  dx/dt = (κ ΔT)/(L ρ x).

Separate variables and integrate from the initial thickness x₀ = 1 cm at time t = 0 to a final thickness x = 2 cm at time t = T:

  x dx = (κ ΔT)/(L ρ) dt.

Integrate both sides:

  ∫₁² x dx = (κ ΔT)/(L ρ) ∫₀ᵀ dt.

The left side gives:

  ∫₁² x dx = [½ x²]₁² = ½ (2² – 1²) = ½ (4 – 1) = 3/2.

Thus

  (3/2) = (κ ΔT)/(L ρ) T.

Solve for T:

  T = (3 L ρ)/(2 κ ΔT).

Now substitute the values:

  T = (3×80×1)/(2×5×10⁻³×20).

First, compute the denominator: 2×5×10⁻³×20 = 2×(0.005×20) = 2×0.1 = 0.2.

Thus

  T = (240)/(0.2) = 1200 sec.

Converting seconds to minutes: 1200 sec ÷ 60 = 20 minutes.

Final Answers:
(a) The ice grows at 0.00125 cm/sec when it is 1 cm thick.
(b) It takes 20 minutes for the ice’s thickness to double from 1 cm to 2 cm.

\[
\boxed{\text{(a) } 0.00125\text{ cm/sec, \quad (b) } 1200\text{ sec (20 minutes)}}
\]

We are given a container divided by a partition with a small hole of diameter D. The two halves contain helium at different temperatures, T₁ = 150 K (side 1) and T₂ = 300 K (side 2), maintained by heating the walls. Since the gas pressure and hence the particle densities in the two chambers will adjust until a steady state is reached, the process by which equilibrium is established depends on the relationship between the hole size D and the molecules’ mean free paths ℓ₁ and ℓ₂.

Let’s analyze each part step by step.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): The Role of the Diameter D

The physical process by which the gases come to a steady state depends on whether collisions occur inside the hole.

1. If D is much smaller than the mean free paths (D ≪ ℓ₁ and D ≪ ℓ₂):
  - When the hole is smaller than the molecular mean free paths, molecules that hit the hole rarely collide with one another inside it. Hence, molecules pass through ballistically.
  - This is the regime of effusion. In effusion, the rate at which molecules pass through the hole depends on their number density n and their thermal speed v (which goes roughly as √T).
  - In a steady state, the number of molecules passing from side 1 to side 2 has to balance that from side 2 to side 1.

2. If D is much larger than the mean free paths (D ≫ ℓ₁ and D ≫ ℓ₂):
  - In this case, the hole is “open” compared to the distance between collisions so that the gas can be treated as a continuum.
  - This results in a more hydrodynamic or viscous (diffusive) flow through the large opening.
  - In such circumstances, equilibrium is achieved by the equalization of the pressures in each chamber.

Thus, the diameter D determines whether equilibration occurs via effusive (ballistic) transport or via viscous (continuum) flow.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Ratio of the Mean Free Paths (ℓ₁/ℓ₂) When D ≪ ℓ₁, ℓ₂

In the effusive regime, the flux (number of molecules per unit time) from each side through the small hole is given by:
  Flux ∝ nᵢ v̄ᵢ,
where nᵢ is the number density in chamber i and the average molecular speed v̄ᵢ is proportional to √Tᵢ. More precisely,
  v̄ᵢ ∝ √Tᵢ  (i = 1, 2).

At steady state, the net mass flow must vanish:
  n₁√T₁ = n₂√T₂.
Thus,
  n₁/n₂ = √(T₂/T₁).

Since the mean free path is given (for a given collision cross‐section σ) by
  ℓᵢ ∝ 1/nᵢ,
we have
  ℓ₁/ℓ₂ = n₂/n₁ = 1/ (n₁/n₂) = √(T₁/T₂).

Substitute the temperatures:
  ℓ₁/ℓ₂ = √(150/300) = √(1/2) = 1/√2.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (c): Ratio of the Mean Free Paths (ℓ₁/ℓ₂) When D ≫ ℓ₁, ℓ₂

In the continuum (viscous or hydrodynamic) flow regime, the gas in the two chambers quickly reaches local equilibrium near the opening. The equilibrium condition is that the pressures must be equal on both sides:
  p₁ = p₂.
Using the ideal gas law (p = n kT), this means:
  n₁T₁ = n₂T₂  ⇒  n₁/n₂ = T₂/T₁.

Now, using ℓᵢ ∝ 1/nᵢ, we get:
  ℓ₁/ℓ₂ = n₂/n₁ = 1/(T₂/T₁) = T₁/T₂.

Substitute the values:
  ℓ₁/ℓ₂ = 150/300 = 1/2.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) If D ≪ ℓ, gas molecules pass through the hole by effusion (ballistic, collisionless transport), while if D ≫ ℓ, the flow is hydrodynamic (viscous, diffusive flow) governed by pressure equilibration.

(b) In the effusive regime (D ≪ ℓ₁, ℓ₂): 
  ℓ₁/ℓ₂ = 1/√2.

(c) In the continuum (viscous) regime (D ≫ ℓ₁, ℓ₂):
  ℓ₁/ℓ₂ = 1/2.

─────────────────────────────

&(a) \; \text{For } D \ll \ell, \text{ equilibration occurs by effusion (ballistic transport), and for } D \gg \ell, \text{ the flow is hydrodynamic.} \\
&(b) \; \frac{\ell_1}{\ell_2} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}. \\
&(c) \; \frac{\ell_1}{\ell_2} = \frac{1}{2}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]
